div.l: (base) Narrat
(base) IN tholde dayes of the kyng Arthour
(base) Of which that Britons speken greet honour
(base) Al was this land fulfild of Fairye
(base) The Elf queene with hir ioly compaignye
(base) Daunced ful ofte in many a grene mede
(base) This was the olde opynyoun as I rede
(base) I speke of many hundred yerys ago
(base) But now kan no man se none Elues mo
(base) For now the grete charitee and prayeres
(base) Of lymytours and othere holy freres
(base) As thikke as any motis in the sonne beme
(base) That serchen euery lond and euery streem
(base) As thikke as motes in the sonne beem
(base) Blessynge halles chambres kichenes boures
(base) Citees Burghes Castels hye Toures
(base) Thropes Bernes Shipnes Dayeryes
(base) This maketh that ther been no fairyes
(base) For ther as wont to walken was an Elf
(base) Ther walketh now the lymytour hymself
(base) In vndermelys and in morwenynges
(base) And seith his matyns and his holy thynges
(base) As he gooth in his lymytacioun
(base) Wommen may go saufly vp and down
(base) In euery bussh or vnder euery tree
(base) Ther is noon oother Incubus but he
(base) And he ne wol doon hem but dishonour
(base) And so bifel that this kyng Arthour
(base) Hadde in his hous a lusty Bachiler
(base) That on a day cam ridyng fro Ryuer
(base) And happed that allone as he was born
(base) He say a mayde walkynge hym biforn
(base) Of which mayde anoon maugree hir hed
(base) By verray force he rafte hir maydenhed
(base) For which oppressioun was swich clamour
(base) And swich pursuyte vnto the kyng Arthour
(base) That dampned was this knyght for to be deed
(base) By cours of lawe and sholde han lost his heed
(base) Par auenture swich was the Statut tho
(base) But that the queene and othere ladyes mo
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) So longe preyden the kyng of grace
(base) Til he his lyf hym graunted in the place
(base) And yaf hym to the queene al at hir wille
(base) To chese wheither she wolde hym saue or spille
(base) The queen thanked þe kyng wiþ al hir might
(base) And after this thus spak she to the knyght
(base) Whan that she saw hir tyme vpon a day
(base) Thow standest yet quod she in swich array
(base) That of thy lyf yet hastow no suretee
(base) That of þi life / yit hastou kanst tel me
(base) I graunte thee lyf if thow kanst tellen me
(base) What thyng is it that wommen moost desiren
(base) Be war and keep thy nekke boon from Iren
(base) And if thow kanst nat tellen me anon
(base) Yet wol I yeue thee leue for to gon
(base) A twelf monthe and a day to seche and lere
(base) An answere suffisant in this matere
(base) And seuretee wol I han er that thow pace
(base) Thy body for to yelden in this place
(base) Wo was this knyght and sorwefully he siketh
(base) But what he may nat doon al as hym liketh
(base) And atte laste he chees hym for to wende
(base) And come agayn right at the yeres ende
(base) With swich answere as god wolde hym purueye
(base) And taketh his leue and wendeth forth his weye
(base) He seketh euery hous and euery place
(base) Where as he hopeth for to fynde grace
(base) To lerne what thyng wommen loue moost
(base) But he ne koude arryuen in no coost
(base) Where as he myghte fynde in this matere
(base) Two creatures acordyng in feere
(base) Somme seyden wommen louen best richesse
(base) Somme seyde honour somme seyde Iolifnesse
(base) Somme riche array somme lust abedde
(base) And ofte tyme to be widwe and wedde
(base) Somme seyde that oure herte is moost esed
(base) Whan that we been yflatered and yplesed
(base) He gooth ful ny the sothe I wol nat lye
(base) A man shal wynne vs best with flaterye
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And with attendaunce and with bisynesse
(base) Been we ylymed bothe moore and lesse
(base) And somme seyn that we louen best
(base) For to be free and do right as vs lest
(base) And that no man repreue vs of oure vice
(base) But seye that we be wise and no thyng nyce
(base) For trewely ther is noon of vs alle
(base) If any wight wolde clawe vs on the galle
(base) That we nyl kike for he seith vs sooth
(base) Assay and he shal fynde it that so dooth
(base) For be we neuer so vicious with Inne
(base) We wol be holden wise and clene of synne
(base) And somme seyn that greet delit han we
(base) For to be holden stable and eek secree
(base) And in o purpos stedefastly to dwelle
(base) And nat biwreye thyng that men vs telle
(base) But that tale is nat worth a Rake stele
(base) Pardee we wommen konne no thyng hele
(base) Witnesse on Mida wol ye heere the tale
(base) Ouyde amonges othere thynges smale
(base) Seyde Mida hadde vnder his longe herys
(base) Growynge vpon his heed two Asses erys
(base) The which vice he hidde as he best myghte
(base) Ful sotilly from euery mannes sighte
(base) That saue his wyf ther wiste of it na mo
(base) He loued hire moost and trusted hire also
(base) He preyed hire that to no creature
(base) She sholde tellen of his disfigure
(base) She swoor hym nay for al this world to wynne
(base) She nolde do that vileynye or syn
(base) To make hir housbonde han so foul a name
(base) She nolde nat telle it for hir owene shame
(base) For repuyng of hem and foule shame
(base) But nathelees hir thoughte that she dyde
(base) That she so longe sholde a conseil hyde
(base) Hir thoughte it swal so soore aboute hir herte
(base) That nedely som word hir moste asterte
(base) And sith she dorste nat telle it to no man
(base) Doun to a Marys faste by she ran
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Til she cam there hir herte was a fyre
(base) And as a Bitore bombleth in the Myre
(base) She leyde hir mouth vnto the water down
(base) Biwrey me nat thow water with thy sown
(base) Quod she to thee I telle it and namo
(base) Myn housbonde hath longe Asses erys two
(base) Now is myn herte al hool now it is oute
(base) I myghte no lenger kepe it out of doute
(base) Heere may ye see thogh we a tyme abyde
(base) Yet out it moot we kan no conseil hyde
(base) The remenant of the tale if ye wol heere
(base) Redeth Ouyde and ther ye may it leere
(base) This knyght of which my tale is specially
(base) Whan that he say he myghte nat come ther by
(base) This is to seye what wommen louen moost
(base) With Inne his brest ful sorweful was the goost
(base) But hom he gooth he myghte nat soiorne
(base) The day was come that homward moste he torne

I have a wyf quod oure Ost though she pore be

¶ Sire Frankeleyn cometh nere / ȝif it youre wil be

(base) For which vnto this Apius they gon
(base) And caste hym in a prison right anon
(base) Ther as he slow hymself and Claudius
(base) That seruant was vnto this Apius
(base) Was demed for to hange vpon a tree
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But that Virginius of his pitee
(base) So preyde for hym that he was exiled
(base) And ellis certes he hadde been bigyled
(base) The remenant were anhanged moore and lesse
(base) That were consentant of this cursednesse
(base) ¶ Heere may men seen how synne hath his merite
(base) Beth war for no man woot whom god wol smyte
(base) In no degree ne in which manere wise
(base) The worm of conscience may agrise
(base) Of wikked lyf thogh it so pryuee be
(base) That no man woot ther of but god and he
(base) For be he lewed man or ellis lered
(base) He noot how soone that he shal been afered
(base) Therfore I rede yow this conseil take
(base) Forsaketh synne er synne yow forsake
(base) ¶ Here endeth the Phisiciens tale
(base) ¶The myry talkyng of the hoost to the Phisicien and the Pardoner
(base) Et Incipit Prologus de la Pardoner cum fabula sua .
(base) Oure hoost gan to swere / as he were wood
(base) Harrow quod he / by nayles and by blood
(base) This was a fals cherl / and a fals Iustise
(base) As shameful deeth / as herte may deuyse
(base) Come to thise Iuges / and hir Aduocatz
(base) So falle vpon his body and his bones
(base) Algate this sely mayde / is slayn allas
(base) Þe deuyl I bekenne him al at ones
(base) Allas / to deere boghte she beautee
(base) Wherfore I seye alday / that men may se
(base) That yiftes of Fortune / and of nature
(base) Been cause of deeth / to many a creature
(base) Her beaute was her deth I dar wel sayn
(base) Allas so pitously as she was slayn
(base) Of bothe yiftes / that I speke of now
(base) But her of wil I not ꝓprocede as now
(base) Hir beaute was hir deþ I dar wel sayn
(base) Men han ful ofte / moore for harm than prow
(base) Hir beaute was hir deth I dar wel sayn
(base) Allas so pitously as she was slayn
(base) ¶ But trewely / myn owene maister deere
(base) This is a pitous tale / for to heere
(base) But nathelees passe ouer is no fors
(base) I pray to god / so saue thy gentil cors
(base) And eek thyne vrynals / and thy Iurdones
(base) Thyn Ypocras / and eek thy galyones
(base) And euery boyste / ful of thy letuarie
(base) God blesse hem / and oure lady Seinte Marie
(base) So mote I then / thow art a propre man
(base) And lyk a prelat / by Seint Ronyan
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Seyde I nat wel / I kan nat speke in terme
(base) But wel I woot thow doost myn herte to erme
(base) That I almoost haue caught a Cardynacle
(base) By corpus bones / but if I haue triacle
(base) Or ellis a draghte / of moyste and corny ale
(base) Or but I heere anon / a murye tale
(base) Myn herte is lost for pitee of this mayde
(base) ¶ Thow beel amy / thow Pardoner he sayde
(base) Tel vs som myrthe / or Iapes right anon
(base) ¶ It shal be doon quod he / by Seint Ronyon
(base) But first quod he / heere at this ale stake
(base) I wol bothe drynke / and eten of a Cake
(base) ¶ And right anon / thise gentils gonne to crye
(base) Nay lat hym telle vs / of no ribawdye
(base) Tel vs som moral thyng / that we may leere
(base) Som wit / and thanne wol we gladly heere
(base) ¶ Gladly quod he and seide as ye shal here
(base) But in the cuppe wol I me bithinke
(base) ¶ I graunte ywis quod he / but I moot thynke
(base) Vpon som honeste thyng whil that I drynke
(base) Here endeth the reheytyng of our hoost
(base) Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas
¶ And here begynneth the tale
Lordynges quod he / in churche whan I pche
I peyne me / to have an hauteyn speche
I rynge it out / as round as goth a belle
For I can al be rote / that I telle
My teeme is alwey oon / and euere was
Radix omnium malorum / est cupiditas
First I ꝓpronounce / whennes that I come
And than my bulles / I shewe alle and some
Oure liege lordes seal / en my patent
That shewe I first / my body to warent
That no man be so bold / preest ne clerk
Me to distourbe / of cristes holy werk
And after that / telle I forth my tales
Bulles of popes / and of cardinales
Of patriarkes / and bisshoppes I shewe
And in latyn / I speke wordes fewe
To sauoure with my pdicaciou
And forto stere men / to deuociou
Then shewe I forth / my longe cristal stones /¶¶
Ycrammed ful of cloutes and of bones
Relikes they ben / as wene they ecchoon
That have I in latou / a shulder boon
Which that was / of an holy Iewes shepe
Good men I sey / take of my wordes kepe
Ȝif that this boon / be wasshen in a welle
Ȝif kow or calf / shepe or Oxe swelle
That any worme hath eten / or stōmnge
Or ellis aboute the herte / or the lonnge
It is hool anoon / and ferthermore
Of pokkes / and of scabbe / and of eủer/rey sore
Shal eủer/rey sheep ben hooll / that of this welle
Drynke a draught / take heed that I telle
If that the goodman / that the bestes oweth
Wol eủer/rey wyke / or that the Cok him croweth
Fastynge drynke / of this welle a draught
As thilke holy Iewes / oure elders taught
His bestes and his store / shal multiplie
And sires also / it heleth Ialousie
And though a man be fallen / in a ialous rage
Lat make wᵗith the water / his potage
And neủer/ree shal he / his wyf mystriste
Though he / the sothe / of hir defaute wiste
Al had she taken / preestes two or thre
Here is a myteyne eke / that ye may se
He that his hand / wol put in this myteyne
He shal have multyplyinge / of his greyne
Whan he hath sowen / be it whete or otes
So that he brynge me goode pans or ellis grotes
And men and women / oo thyng I warne yow
If any wight / be in this churche now
That hath done synne / horible that he
Dar not for shame / of it shryven be
Or any woman / be she yong or olde
That hath made hir husbond Cokewold
Suche folke shul have noo power / ne no gᵃce
To offre to my relikes / in this place
And who so fyndeth hym / out of suche blame ¶¶
They may come vp / and offre in godes name
And I assoille hem / by the auctorite
Suche as by my bulles / was graunted me
By this gaude / have I wonnon eủer/rey yere
An hundred mark / syn I was pardoner
I stonde lyk a Clerk / in my pulpitte
And shewe to lewed peple thynges vnshitte
I preche so / as I have lered bifore
And telle an hundred iapes more
Than peyne I me / to strecche forth the nekke
And est and west / vppon the peple I bekke
As doth a dowve / sittynge vpon a berne
Myn handes and my tunge / goon ful yerne
That it is ioye / to se my besynesse
Of Auarice / and suche cursednesse
Is al my pchynge / forto make hem fre
To yeue her pans / namely vnto me
For myn entente is not / but forto wynne
And no thyng / for correcciou of synne
I recche neủer/ree / whan that they be buried
Though that her soules / goo a blakburied
For certes / many a pdicaciou
Cometh ofte tyme / of euel entenciou
Some for plesance of folc / and for flaterie
Sōmme ben auaunced / by ypocrisie
And some for venglorie / and for hate
For whan I dar not / other wayes debate
Than wole I stinge hem / with my tunge smert
In pchyng / so that he shal not stert
To ben defamed falsly / so that he
Hath trespassed to my brethern / and to me
For though I telle not / his ꝓpropre name
Men shal wel knowe / that it is the same
By som signe / and other circumstances
Thus smyte I folk / that doth vs displesances
Thus spitte I out my venyme / vnder hewe
Of holynesse / to seme good and trewe
But shortly myn entente / I wol deuise ¶¶
I preche no thyng / but of couetise
Therfore my teme / is and eủer/ree was
Radix omnium malorum / est cupiditas
Thus can I preche / ageyn the same vice
Whiche that I vse / and that is auarice
But though my self / be gilty in that synne
Yit can I make / other folke to wynne
Fro auarice / and sore hem repente
But that is nouȝt / my principal entente
I preche not / but for couetise
Of this matere / it ought ynow suffise
Than telle I hem / ensamples manyoon
Of olde stories / long tyme a goon
For lewed peple / louen tales olde
Suche thinges con they / reporte and holde
What trowe ye / whiles that I may preche
And wynne golde / and syluer for to teche
That I wol lyue in pouert wilfully
Nay nay I thought it neủer/ree trewely
For I wol preche / and begge in sundry londes
I wol do noo labour / with my hondes
Ne maken baskettes / and lyue therby
By cause I wol nouȝt / lyuen ydelly
I wol noon of the Appostelles countrefete
I wol have moneye / chese or whete
Al were it yeven / of the poủer/reest page
Or of the pouerest widewe / in a village
Al shulde hir childerne sterue / or famyne
And I wol drenken / the licour of the wyne
And have a ioly wenche / in euery toun
But herkeneth lordes / in conclusioun
Youre lykyng is / that I shal telle a tale
Now I have dronken / a draughte of corny ale
By god I hope / I shall telle you a thyng
That by reson / shal be to youre lykyng
For thogh my self / be a vicious man
A moral tale / ȝit I you telle can
Whiche Iames wente to preche / forto wynne ¶¶
Now holdeth youre pees / my tale I wol bigynne
In Flaundres whilom / ther was a companye
Of yong folk / that haunted folye
As hasard / riot / stewes / and tauernes
Harpes rubibes / lutes and / gyternes
They dauncen and playen / atte dys nyght ⁊and day
And eete also / ouer that myght may
For they do to the deuel sacrifice
Withynne the deuelles temple / in sondry wise
By suꝑper/parfluite / abhominable
Her othes ben so greet / and dampnable
That it is grisely / forto here hem swere
Oure blessed lordes body / they to tere
Hem thoughte Iewes / rente hym nough ynogh
And eche of hem / at others synne logh
And right anoon / come in the tumblisters
Fetise and smale / and yonge fruters
Syngers wᵗith harpes / baudes and waferers
Suche ben verrayly / the Deuels officers
To kyndely and blowe / the fire of leccherie
That is annexed / vnto glotenie
Holy writte / take I to witnesse
That leccherie is in wyn / and in drunkenesse
Loo how that drunken Loth / vnkyndely
Lay by his doghters two / vnwetingely
So dronken he was / he niste what he wroght
Herodes / who so hath the stories souȝt
Whan he of wyn / was replete atte feste
Right at his owne table ȝaf hes heste
To sleen the Iohn Baptist / ful gilteles
Senec seith a good worde douteles
He seith he can / no difference fynde
Betwixe a man / þᵗat is out of his mynde
And a man / that is drounkelewe
But that wodnesse / is fallen in a shrewe
Perseủer/reeth lenger / than doth drunkenesse
Of glotenie ful / of cursednesse
O cause first / of oure confusiou ¶¶
Original / of oure dampnaciou
Til crist had bouȝt vs / with his blood ageyn
Lo how dere shortely for to seyn
Abought was / the cursed vilanie
Corrupte was al this world thurgh glotenie
Adam oure Fader / and his wyf also
Fro paradys / to labour and to wo
Were dreven for that wise / it is no drede
For whiles / that Adam fasted / as I rede
He was in paradys / and whan that he
Eet of the fruyt / defended on the tree
Anoon he was outcast / to wo and pyne
Of glotenie / on the wel oughte vs pleyne
O wist a man / how many maladyes
Folweth of excesse / and of glotenyes
He wolde ben / the more mesurable
Of his diete / sittinge at his table
Allas the short throte / the tendre mowth
Maketh that est and west / north and sowth
In erthe / in eyer / in water men to swynke
To geten a gloten / deynte mete and drynke
Of this matere / o paule wel canstow trete
Mete vnto wombe / and wombe eke vnto mete
Shal god destroye / bothe as paule seith
Allas a foule thinge / it is by my feith
To say this word / and fouler is the dede
Whan men so drynketh / of the white and rede
That of his throte / he maketh his pryuite
Thurgh thilke cursed super fluyte
The Apostil wepynge / seith ful pitousely
Ther walken manye / of whiche tolde have I
I say it now wepynge / wᵗith pitous voys
They ben enemyes / of crystes croys
Of whiche the ende is deth / wombe is her god
O wombe o baly / o stynkynge cod
Fulfilled of dong and of corrupciou
At eyther of the / foul is the sesou
How grete cost and labour / is to fynde ¶¶
Thise Cookes how they stampe / streyne and grynde
And turne substance / into accident
To fulfille all / thy lykerous talent
Out of the harde bones / knokke they
The mary / for they cast it not awey
That may go thurgh the golet / softe and swote
Of specery / of leues / bark and rote
Shal ben his savce / ymaad be delite
To maken him ȝit / a newe appetite
But certes he / that haunteth suche delites
Is ded / whyles he lyueth / in tho vices
And lecherous thing is wyn / and dronkenes
It is ful of stryuyng / and of wrecchednes
O dronken man / disfigured in thy face
Foul is thy breth / foul art thou to enbrace
And thurgh thy dronken nose / sowneth thy soun
As though thou seidest ay / sampsou sampsoun
And ȝit god woot / Sampson dranke neủer/ree wyn
Thow fallest as it were / a dronken swyn
Thy tonge is lost / and al thyn honeste cure
For dronkenes / is verray sepulture
Of mannes wit / and his discreciou
In whom that drynke hath dominaciou
He can noo counseile kepe / it is no drede
Now kepe you / fro the white and fro the rede
Namely fro the white wyn / of leepe
That is to selle in fisshstrete in chepe
Thys wyn of spayne / crepeth subtyly
In other wynes / growyng fast by
Of whiche riseth / suche fumosite
Than whan a man / hath dronken a drauȝt two or thre
And weneth that he be / at home in chepe
Than is he in spayne / right at the toun of lepe
Nought at the Rochell / ne at Burdeaux toun
And than wol they say / Sampsou Sampsoun
But herkeneth lordynges / o word I you pray
That alle the soủer/reayne actes / dar I say
Of victories / in the olde testament ¶¶
That thurgh verray god / that is omipotent
Were done / in abstynence and in prayere
Loketh the bible / and there ye may it lere
Loketh Attila / the grete conquerour
Deyed in his slepe / wᵗith shame and dishonour
Bledynge at his nose / in dronkenesse
A Capitayne shul lyue / in sobornesse
And ouer al this / auise you right wel
¶ What was cōmmaunded / vnto Lamuel
Not Samuel / but Lamuel say I
Redeth the bible / and fyndeth it expssely
Of wyn yevyng / of hem that are Iustice
No more of this / for it may suffice
And now that I have spoken of gloteny
Now wol I defende / you hasardy
¶ Hasard is verray moder / of lesynges
And of desceyte cursed forswerynges
Blaspheme of crist manslaghter ⁊and wast also
Of batayle / and of tyme / and ferther mo
It is repreef / and contrarie to honour
For to be holden / a comou hasardour
And eủer/ree the hyer / he is of estate
The more he is / holden desolate
Ȝif that a prince / vse hasardie
In all goủer/renance / and policie
He is as by comou opiniou
Holde the lasse / in reputaciou
Stilbon a . man þat was holde / a wys enbassatour
Was sent into Corinthe / with ful grete honour
Fro Calidoyne / to make hem alliance
And whan he cam / happed this chaunce
That alle the gretest / that were of that londe
Pleyinge atte hasard / he hem fond
For which as sone / as it myght be
He stal hym home / aȝen to his cuntre
And seide there / wolde I not lese my name
I wolde take nought on me / so grete diffame
For to allie you / to nonne hasardours ¶¶
Sendeth other wyser embassatours
As by my will and by me trete
Than I shulde you / to hasardours allie
For ye that ben so glorious in honoures
Shal not allie you / wᵗith hasardoures
As by my will / ne as by my trete
This wise philosophre thus saide he
Loke eke that to kyng Demetrius
They of pardes / as the book seith thus
Sent hym a payre of dees of gold in scorne
For he had vsed hasardry / ther biforne
For which heeld / his glorie and his renou
For no value / of reputaciou
Lordes myght fynde / other maner play
Honest ynow / to dryve the day away
¶ Now wol I speke / of othes false and grete
A worde or two / as other bokes trete
Greet sweryng / is a thyng abhominable
And fals sweryng / is more reprouable
The high god forbad / sweryng at al
Witnesse of Matheu / but in special
Of swerynge / the holy Ieromie
Thow shalt swere soth / thyn oþes ⁊and not lye
And swere in dome / and eke in rightwisnes
But ydel sweryng / is a cursednes
Beholde and see / that in the first table
Of the high goddes hestes honurable
How that oon heste of hem is this
Take nouȝt my name in ydelnes amys
Lo rather he forbedeth / such sweryng
Than homicide / or any other thyng
I say as thus / by ordre it stondeth
This knoweth / that his hestes vnderstondeth
How that the secunde heste / of god is that
And further oủer/re / I wol the telle al plat
That vengeance shal not passe fro his hous
That of his othes / is so outrageous
By goddes pcious herte / and by his nayles ¶¶
And by his blood that is in hayles
Seuen is my chaunce / as is fyve and thre
By goddes armes / ȝif thou falsly play me
This dagger shal thurgh thyn herte go
This fruyt cometh / of thilke bones two
For sweryng Ire / falsnes homicide
Now for the loue of crist / that for vs deyde
Leveth youre othes / bothe grete and smale
For I shal telle you / a mvaylous tale
Thise Riotours / of whiche I telle
Longe erst or prime / rong eny belle
Were sett in a taủer/rene to drynke
And as they sate / they herde a belle ryng
Before a corps / was caried to his grave
That oon of hem / gan calle to his knave
Go bet quod he / and aske redely
What corps is that / that passith forth by
And that thou reporte / his name wel
Sire quod this knave / it nedeth neủer/ree adel
It was me tolde / er ȝe come here two houres
He was ꝑper/parde / an olde felawe of youres
And sodeinly was he slayn / to nyght
For dronken as he sat / vpon his benche vpright
Ther come a puy theef / men clepe deth
That in his countre / al the peple sleeth
And with his spere / he smote his herte a two
And wente his way / wᵗithoute wordes mo
He hath a thousand slayn / this pestilence
And maist̉er/re er come / to his psence
Me thenketh / that it were necessarie
Forto be war / of suche an aduersarie
Beth redy forto meten him eủer/reemore
Thus tauȝte me my dame I say no more
By seint Marie / seide this tauerner
The childe saith soth / for he hath slayn to ȝere
Hennes over a myle / withynne a grete village
Bothe man and woman child and page
I trowe his habitaciou be there ¶¶
To ben avised / grete wysdam it were
Or that he dide aman / dishonour
Ȝe goddes armes / quod this Riotour
Is it such perile / wᵗith hym forto mete
I shal hym sechyn / by sty and by strete
I make a vow / by goddes digne bones
Herkeneth felawes / we thre ben alle ones
Lat eche of vs / holde vp his hand to other
And eche of vs bicome / others brother
And we wol sle / this fals traytour deth
He shal be slayn / that so many sleth
By goddes dignite / er hit be nyght
To gider han thise thre / her trouthes plight
To lyue and dye / ech of hem with other
As though he were / his owne born brother
And vp they sterten / and dronken in this rage
And forth they goon / toward that vilage
Of which the taủer/rener / hath spoke biforn
And many a grisly othe / than have they sworn
And cristes blessed body / they to rente
That deth shal be ded / ȝif we may hym hente
Whan they haue goon / not fully a myle
Right as they wolde have troden oủer/re a style
An olde and a pore man / wᵗith hem mette
This olde man / ful mekely hem grette
And saide thus / now lordes / god you se
The proudest of thise Riatours thre
Answerde ageyn / what cherl wᵗith hardy gᵃce
Why artow al forwrapped / saue thy face
Why lyuest thou so longe / in so gret age
This olde man gan loke in his visage
And saide thus / for I can not fynde
A man / thogh I walked into ynde
Neither in Citee / ne in no village
That wol chaungen his youthe / for myn age
And therfore mote I have myn age stille
As longe tyme / as it is goddes wille
Ne deth allas wol not have my lyf ¶¶
Thus walke I lyk / a resteles caytyf
And on the grounde / which is my moder gate
I knokke wᵗith my staf / bothe erly and late
And say leue moder / late me Inne
Lo how I wanshe / flessh blood and skynne
Allas whan shul my bones / ben at reste
Moder wᵗith you / wol I chaunge my cheste
That in my chamber / long tyme hath be
Ȝe for an hier cloute to wrappe me
But ȝit to me / she wol not done that gᵃce
For whiche fulwelked is my face
But sires to you / it is no curtesie
To speken vnto an olde man velonie
But he trespace in worde / or in dede
In holy writt / ȝe may ȝoure self rede
Agayn an olde man hoor / vpon his hede
Ye shul avise you / therfore I you rede
Ne doth vnto an olde man / harme as now
No more than ȝe wolde / a man dede to yow
In age ȝif that ȝe so longe abide
And god be with ȝou / wheither ȝe go or ryde
I mote go thider / as I have to go
Nay olde cherle / by god þou shalt not so
Seide thise other hasardours anoon
Thow ꝑper/partest not so lightly by seint Iohn
Thow spake right now / of thilke traytoᵘur deth
That in this countre / alle oure frendes sleeth
Have heer my trouthe / as thou art his aspie
Telle where he is / or ellis thou shalt dye
Be god / and by the holy sacrament
For sothly / thou art of his assent
To sleen vs yonge folk / thou fals theef
Now sires / ȝif it be you so leef
To fynde deth / turne vp this croked way
For in that groue / I lefte hym by my fay
Vnder a tree and there he wol abide
Ne for youre boost / he wol hym no thyng hide
Se ȝe that ook / right there / ȝe shul hym fynde ¶¶
God save you / that bouȝt ageyn mankynde
And ȝow amende / thus saide this olde man
And eủer/rey of thise riotours ran
Til they come to the tre / and there they founde
Floreyns of gold fyne ycoyned rounde
Wel nygh a vij busshels / as hem thought
No lenger than after deth they sought
But eche of hem / so glad was of that sight
For that the Floreynes / so faire were and bright
That doun they sette hem / by that pcious hoord
The werst of hem / spak the first word
Bretheren quod he / take hede what I say

div.ab: (base) Here bigynneth Chaucers tale of Melibeus

(base) A yong man whilom called Melibeus myghty and
riche bigat vp on his wif that called was Prudence a
doghter which that called was Sophie

(base) vp on a day bifel that
he for his desport is went in to the feeldes hym to pleye

(base) his
wif and eek his doghter hath he laft inwith his hous of which
the dores weren faste yshette
(base) thre of his olde foos han it espied and setten laddres to the walles of his hous and by wyndowes ben entred

(base) and betten his wif and wounded his doghter with
fyue mortal woundes in fyue sondry places

(base) this is to seyn
in hir feet in hir handes in hir erys in hir nose and in hir
mouth and leften hire for deed and wenten awey

(base) Whan Melibeus retourned was in to his hous and seigh al this meschief he
lyk a mad man rentynge his clothes gan to wepe and crye

(base) Prudence his wyf as ferforth as she dorste bisoughte hym of
his wepyng for to stynte

(base) but nat for thy he gan to crye and
wepen euere lenger the moore

(base) This noble wif Prudence
remembred hire vp on the sentence of Ouyde in his book that
cleped is the remedie of loue wher as he seith

(base) he is a fool
that destourbeth the moder to wepe in the deth of hir child
til she haue wept hir fille as for a certeyn tyme

(base) and thanne
shal man doon his diligence with amyable wordes hire to reconforte and preye hire of hir wepyng for to stynte

(base) for which
reson this noble wyf Prudence suffred hir housbonde for to
wepe and crye as for a certeyn space

(base) and whan she say hir
tyme she seyde hym in this wise Allas my lord quod she
why make ye your self for to be lyk a fool
(base) for sothe it aperteneth nat to a wys man to maken swich a sorwe

(base) yowre
doghter with the grace of god shal warisshe and escape

(base) And al were it so that she right now were deed ye ne oghte nat as
for hir deth youre self to destroye

(base) Senec seith the wise man
shal nat take to greet disconfort for the deth of his children

(base) but
certes he sholde suffren it in pacience as wel as he abideth the
deth of his owene propre perrsone

(base) This Melibeus answerde anon
and seyde What man quod he sholde of his wepyng stynte
that hath so gret a cause for to wepe

(base) Ihus crist oure lord hym
self wepte for the deth of lazarus his freend

(base) Prudence
answerde Certes wel I woot attempree wepynge is no thyng
defended to hym that
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
sorweful is amonges folk in sorwe but
it is rather graunted hym to wepe

(base) The Apostle Poul vn to
the Romayns writeth Man shal reioysse with hem that maken ioye
and wepen with swich folk as wepen
(base) but thogh attempree wepyng be graunted outrageous wepyng certes is defended

(base) Mesure
of wepyng sholde be considered after the loore that techeth vs
Senec

(base) Whan that thy freend is deed quod he lat nat thyne eyen
to moyste ben of terys ne to muche drye al thogh the teerys
come to thyne eyen lat hem nat falle

(base) And whan thou hast
forgoon thy freend do diligence to geten another freend and
this is moore wysdom than for to wepe for thy freend which
that thou hast lorn for ther Inne is no boote

(base) And therfore if ye
gouerne yow by Sapience put awey sorwe out of youre herte

(base) Remembre yow that Ihus Syrak seith A man that is ioyous and
glad in herte it hym conserueth florisshynge in his age but
soothly sorweful herte maketh his bones drye

(base) he seith eek
thus that sorwe in herte sleeth ful many a man

(base) Salomon
seith that right as Moththes in the Shepes flees anoyeth
to the clothes and the smale wormes to the tree right so anoyeth sorwe to the herte

(base) wher fore vs oghte as wel in the deth
of oure children as in the losse of oure goodes temporels haue
pacience

(base) Remembre yow vp on the pacient Iob whan he
hadde lost his children and his temporel substance and in his body
endured and receyued ful many a greuous tribulacion yet seide
he thus
(base) Oure lord quod he hath yeue it me

(base) Oure lord hath biraft it me right so as oure lord
hath wold right so it is doon yblessed be the name of oure
lord

(base) To thise forseyde thynges answerde Melibeus vn to
his wif Prudence Alle thy wordes quod he been sothe and
ther to profitable but trewely myn herte is troubled with this
sorwe so greuously that I noot what to doon

Prudence thy trewe freendes alle and thy lynage whiche that

alle thy thynges by conseil and thow shalt neuere repente

callen a greet congregacioun of folk

(base) as Sirurgiens Phisiciens
olde folk and yonge and somme of hise olde enemys reconsiled as
by hir semblant to his loue and in to

his grace

vp on this matere

fore vn to oure Art it is nat pertinent to norice werre ne parties

(base) hise neghebores ful of enuye hise

(base) Lordynges the nede for the which

(base) by cause of the wrong and of the wikkednesse that

(base) And ek
by reson of the grete richesse and power of the parties bothe

(base) Wher fore Melibeus this is oure sentence we conseile
yow abouen alle thyng that right anon thow
