div.l: And here bygynneth the Prolog of the Monke his Tale /
I Wil be waile in maner of Tregedie /
The harme of hem / that stonden in high degre
And fallen so that ther nys no remedie
To bryng hem out of her aduersite
For certeyn whan that fortune lust to flee
Ther may no man of here the cours witholde
Beth ware / by these ensamples / yonge and olde /
At Lucifer thogh he an Angell were /
And noght a man / at hym I wil begynne
For though fortune / may non Angel dere /
From high degre / yet felle he for his synne
Doon into helle / wher as he yit is Inne /
Of Lucifer / brightest of Angelys alle /
Now art thou Sathanas / that maist not twynne
Out of Myserie / in which thou art falle in
¶ Lo Adam whiche oure fỏer/reme fader was
Begeled was thorwe fendes tysynge /
Wherthorugh we alle myghten seien allas
Ne hadde be the birth of our lordes comynge
Wherfore alle gan to sprynge /
Amonge the puple / thorgh vertue of his birth
For that we mowe in herte singynge /
Both maken ioie gladnesse and myrth
¶ Lo Sampson which was anunciate
By the Angel longe er his natyuyte
And was to god almyghty consecrate
And stoode in noblesse / whiles he myght se
Was never such another as was he /
To speke of strenght / and therto hardynesse
But to his wiffes told he his secre /
Thorgh which / he slowe hym self for wrecchednesse /
Sampsou this noble and myghty Champiou
With oute wepen / sauf his handes tweye /
He slowe and alto rent the liou
Toward his weddng / walkyng by the weye /
His false wif couthe hym so plese and preye /
Til she his counseil knewe / and she vntrewe
Vnto his foos his consell gan by wreye
And hym forsoke / and toke another newe /
An hundred foxes toke Sampsou for Ire
And here tailles alle / he to geder bounde
And sett the foxes tailes al on a fire
For he in euery tayle had putt a bronde
And they brent alle / the cornes in that lande
And all here Olyues / and here vynes eke
A Mˢ men he slough eke wᵗith his hande
And had noo wepen / but an asses cheke
Whan they weren slayen so thrested hym that he
Was wel nygh lorn / for whiche he gan to preie
That god wold of his peine have pyte
And sende hym drenke / or ellis most hym deie /
And of his asses cheke / that was so dreye /
Out of a wang toth / spronge anou / a well
Of whiche he dranke ynowe shortly to seye
Thus holpe hym god / as Iudiciu can telle /
By verrey force at gason on a nyght
Maugre philistians of that Cite
The gates of the Toune he hath up plight
And on his bak ycaried hem hath he
Hegh on a hille / wher as men myght se /
O noble and myghty Sampson lief and dere
That so stronge so noble and myghty hast be
In al this world ther nas never thy pere /
This Sampsou / never sider dronke ne wyne /
Ne on his heved come rasour nou ne sheer
By pcept of the massager devyne
For al his strenght was in his heer
And fully twenty yere by yere
He hadde of Israel the gouernance
But after soon shall he wepe mony a teere
For wōmmen shul brynge hym to myschaunce /
Vnto his lemman Dalida he tolde
That in his heeres al his strength lay
And falsly to his foomen / she hym solde
And slepyng on hir barme vpon a day
She made to clippe or sheere his heer away
And made his foomen al his craft espien
And whan that they hym founden in suche aray
They bounde hym fast and put out his eyen
But or heer were iclipped or Ishave
There was no bonde that myght hym bynde /
But nowe is he in prison put in a kave /
Wher as they made hym at the querne grynde
O noble Sampsou strengest of mankynde
O whilom Iuge in glorie and richesse /
Thou maist now wepe / wᵗith thyin yen blynde
Seth thou art from wele fallen into wracchednesse /
The ende of this Catif / was as I shal saye
His foomen made a fest vpon a day
And made hym as here fool biforn hem pleye
And this was at the temple of grete Aray
But at the last / he made a foule affray
For he two postes shoke / and made hem falle
And doune fille temple / and al ther it lay
And slough hym self / and eke his foomen alle /
This is to seien the prynces eủer/reychou /
And eke a Mˢ bodies were there slayn
With falleng of the grete temple of ston
Of Sampsou ne wil I no more saien
Beth ware of thise ensaumples olde and pleyn
That no man tel here counsel to her wyves
Of suche thynge / as they wolde have secre fayn
If that touche hir lymmes or hir lyves /
Of hercule the soủer/reaigne Conqueroᵘur
Syngen his werkes high and lowe / renon /
For in his tyme of strength he bere the floᵘur
He slough / and raft the skyn fro the lyou
He of Sentawers leide the boost a dou /
He Arpies slough the cruel briddes felle
He golden apples / raft the dragou
He drowe out Serberois the hounde of helle /
He slough the cruel tyraunt Buserus
And made his hors to frete hym flessh and bon
And slough the verray serpent venemous
Of Achilles / two hornes / he breke on
And he slough kacus in a kaue of ston
He slough the geant Anteus the stronge
He slough the grisly Boor / and that anon
And bare the hede vpon his nek longe /
Whas never wight sithe the world bygan
That slough so mony monslers as did he /
Thorgh out the world / his name ran
What for his strenght / and for his bonte /
And euery Reme / went he forto see /
He was so stronge / that no man myght hym lett
And bothe the worldes ende saith Trophe /
Instede of Bondas / he a pilere sette /
A lemman had this noble Campiou
That hight diamyre / fresche as may
And as Clerkes maken mensiou /
She hath hym sent / a shert fressh and gay
Allas this sherte / and wel away
Envenymed was subtelly with all
That er he had wered it half a day
Hit made his bones from his flessh falle /
But nathelees some clerkes hir excusen .
By oon that hight Nessus that it maked
Be as be may I wil hir not excusen
But on his bak / tho shert he werth al naked
Til that the Flessh was for the venym blaked
And whan he segh noon other remedye
In hote cooles he hath hym self raked
For wᵗith no venyme / deyned he to deye /
This starf this worthy ghty Ercules
Loo who may trest on fortune eny throwe
For hym that foloweth / al the world of prees /
Er he be ware / is oft yleide ful lowe /
Ful wise is he / that hym self can knowe /
Be ware / for whan that fortune list to glose
Than waiteth she hur . man dou throwe
By suche a way / as he wolde lest suppose /
The myghty Trone the pcious tresour
The glorious scepter and real mageste
That had the kynge Nabugodonosor
With tonge vnneth may discrived be
Hie twies nam Ierusalem the cite
The vessel of the temple he wᵗith hym ladde
At Babiloyne was his souerayne See
In whiche his glorie and his delite he hadde
The fairest Childer of the blood Roiall
Of Ierlm he did do geeld anou
And made eche of hem to bene his thrall
Amonge al other Danyel was oon .
That was the wisest child of eủer/reychon /
For he the dremes of the kyng expouned
Wher as in Calday / Clerk was ther nou
That wist to what fyne / here dremes souned
This proude kyng lett make a stature of gold
Syxty cubytes longe / and vij in brede
To whiche ymage / bothe yonge and olde
Comaunded he to loute / and have in drede
Or in a fourneis ful of flammes rede
He shal be brent / that wol not obeye
But never wolde assent / to that dede
Danyel ne his yonge felowes tweye
This kyng of kynges proude and Elate
He wend god that sitte in Magistee
Ne myght hym not bireve of his estate
But sodenly he lost his dignytee
And like a beest him semeth forto be
And eete hay as an Oxe / and lay therout
In reyne with wilde bestes walked he
Tyl certeyn tyme was come about
And ilike an Egles fethers were his eeres
His nayles lyke to clowes of briddes were
God releued hym at certeyn yeres
And yaf hym witte / and than wᵗith mony a tere
He thonked god and ever his lif in fere
Was he to don amys / or moor t̉er/respasse
And or that tyme ileide was on his bere
He knewe well / that god was ful of myght and gᵃce /
¶ His sone which that hight Balthasare
That heelde the Beaume after his Fader day
He by his fadere couth not be ware
For proude he was of herte / and of aray
And eke an ydolatre was he aye
His highe estate assured him in pride
But fortune cast hym dou / and ther he lay
And sodeynly his regne gan devyde /
A feest he made vnto his lordes alle /
Vppon a tyme / he made hem blith be
And than his Offic̉er/res gan he calle
Goth bryngeth forth the vessels quod he
Which that my Fader in his ꝓprosꝑper/parite
Out of temple of Ierlm byrafte
And to oure goddes thonke we
Of honours that oure elders with vs lafte
His wif his lordes / and his Concubynes
Ay dronken / the whiles her appetit laste
Out of thise noble vesselles sondry wynes
And on a walle / this kyng his eyen caste
And segh an hande Armeles that wrote ful faste
For feer / of which he quoke / and sighed soor
This hand / that made Baltazar so soor agaste
Wrote Mane techel phares / and no more
In al that lande / Magicien was ther non
That couthe expoune / what this letter ment
But Danyel expouned it anou
And seide kyng / god / thy Fader sent
Glorie and honoᵘur regne tresour and rent
And he was proude / and no thyng god ne dradde
And therfore / god grete wreche vppon hym sente
And hym biraft the regne / that he hadde /
He was out . cast / of mannys companye
With asses / was his habitaciou
And eete hay as a best in wete and drye
Tyl that he knewe by grace / and by resou
That god of heven hath domynaciou
Ouer euery regne / and euery creature
And than had god of hym compassiou
And hym restored his regne / and his figure /
Eke thou thart his sone / art proude also /
And knowest all thise thynges prively
And rebelle to god / and art his Foo /
Thou dronke eke / of his vessellis boldely
Thy wiff eke / and thy wenches sinfully
Dranke of the same vessell sondry wynes
And heried fals godes cursedly
Therfore to the shapen grete peyne is
This hande was sent fro god / that on the walle
That wrote / Mane techel phares / trest me
Thy regne is don / thou weiest not at alle /
Devided is the regne / and it shal be
To medes and parses / yeven quod he
And thylke same nyght / the kyng was slawe /
And Darius occupyeth his degree
They he therto nad nother right ne lawe
Lordynges her by ensample may ye take
How that in lordshyp nys no sikernesse
For whan fortune wil a man for sake
He bereth a way his regne / and his richesse
And eke his frendes / bothe more and lesse
And what man hath frendes / thorgh fortune
Mishappe wil make hevynesse I gesse
This ꝓproverbe is ful soth / and ful comune
Cenobia and palimer the Quene
As writen ꝑper/parisience of here noblesse
So worthy was in armes / and so kene
That no wight / passed here in hardynesse
Ne in lynage / ne in other gentilnesse /
Of kynges blood of percy / es she descended
I sey that she made is not most of fairenesse
But of shap / she myght not be amended
From hir childhode / I fynde that she flodde
Office of wōmmen / and to the wode she wente
And mony a wilde hertes blood she shedde
With arowes brode / that she to hem sente
She was so swift / that she anon hem hente
And whan that she was elder / she wolde kylle
Lyons / leoperdes / and beeres alto rente /
And in heere armes / welden hem at here wille /
She dorste wildes beestes Dennes seke
And renne in the mounteyn al the nyght
And slepen vndre the bussh / and couth eke
Wrastel by verray force / and verrey myght
With eny yonge man / wher he never so wight
Ther myght no thyng in her armes stonde
She kept hire maidenhode fro eủer/rey wight
To no man deyned she to be bounde /
But at last / here frendes han here maried
To Odonake a prince of that countre
Al were it so / that she hem longe taried
And ye shul vnderstande / how that he
Hadde suche fantasies / as hadde she
But nathalees / whan they were knyt in fere
They leved in Ioie / and in felicitee
For eche of hem had other lief and dere /
Sauf oo thynge / that she nolde never assent
By no way / that he shulde by here lye /
But ones / for it was hir pleyn entent
To have a childe / the worlde to multiplie
And also sone / as she myght espie /
That she was not with childe / wᵗith that dede
Than wolde she suffre hym doon his fantasie
Eft sone / and nat but ones out of drede
And if she were with childe in thilke caste
No more shulde he pleye thilke game
Til fully xl daies were paste
Than wolde she / ones do suffre hym the same /
Al were this Onedak wilde or tame
He gate no more of hure / but thus she seide
It was to wyves leccherie and shame
In other caas / if that men with hem pleide /
Twoo sones by this Odenak had she /
The whiche she kept in vertue and in letterure /
But nowe vnto oure tale turne we
I say that wirshupful creature
And wys ther with / and large wᵗith mesure
And pesebly in the werre / and curteise eke
No more labour myght in werre endure
Was non / though al this world men shulde seke /
Here riche array myght not be tolde
As wel in vessell / as in clothynge
She was al clad in perry and in gold
And eke she laft not for non huntenge
To have of sondry tonges folk knowynge
Whan she leiser hadde / and forto entende
To lerne bookes / was al here likynge
How she in vertue / myght hir lyf dispende /
And shortly of this storie forto entrete
So doughtely was he husbonde as she /
That they conquered mony regnes grete
In the orient with mony a faire Citee
Apꝑper/partenent vnto the mageste
Of Rome / and with stronge heelde hem faste
Ne never myght hir foomen doon hem slee
Ay whiles that Odenak daies laste /
Her batailles who so lust hem forto rede /
Ageyn Sapor the kyng and other moo /
And how that al this prossesse fille in dede
Whi she conquered / and what title had therto
And after of hir meschief and her woo
How she was byseged / and itake /
Lat him vnto my Maist̉er/re petrak goo
That writ ynowe / of this I vnderstande /
Whan Odenake was dede she myghtely
The regnes heelde / and wᵗith here ꝓpropre hande
Ayenst hir foos / she fought trewely
That ther nas kynge ne prynce in al that lande
That he nas glad / yf he that gᵃce fande
That she ne shulde vppon hem werrey
With hire they maden aliaunce by bounde
To bene in pees / and let here ryde and pley
The Emꝑper/paroᵘur of Rome Claudius
Ne hym byforn the Romayne galien
Ne durst never be so coragius
Ne non hermenye / ne non Egipcien
Ne Surreyne ne none Arabyene
With Inne the feelde / that durst wᵗith hire fight
Lest that she wolde / hem with here handes sleen
Or with here mayne / putten hem to flyght .
In kynges Abyte went her sones twoo
As heires of here regnes alle
And hermanno / and thymalao
Here names were / as ꝑper/parisience hem calle
But fortune hath ay in here hony ; galle /
This myghty Quene / may noo while endure
Fortune out of hure regne made hure falle
To wrecchednesse / and to Misauenture /
Aurelion whan that / þᵗat the goủer/renᵃnce
Of Rome / come into his handes tweye /
He shoop vppon this Quene to do vengeance
And with his legioıı̄uns he toke his weye
Toward Cenobie / and shortly forto seye
He made her flee / and at the laste here hent
And fettred here / and eke hir childern tweye
And wan the londe / and home to Rome he went
Amonge thise other thynges that he wan
Hure Chare / that was with golde wroght and perry
This grete Romayn / this Aurelian
Hath with hym lad / for that men shuld see
Biforne his Trisumphe walked she
With gilt Cheynes or here nek hanginge
Corowned she was as after here degre
And ful of perry charged her clothynge /
Allas fortune / she that whilom was
Dredfull to kynges / and to Emꝑper/parours /
Nowe gaureth all the puple on hire allas
And she that helmed was in stark stoures /
And wan by force / Townes stronge and Towres
Shal on here hede / nowe bere a vitremyte
And she that bere the Septer ful of Floures
Shal bere a distaf / he cost forto quyte /
¶ O noble worthy petir glorie of Speyne
Whom fortune heelde so high in Mageste
Wel ought men / thy pitous deth compleyne
Thy bastard brother / made the for flee
And after at a Sege by subtilite
Thou were bitrayed / and lad vnto his Tent
Wher as he with his owne hande slowe the /
Succedyng in thi regne and in thy rent .
¶ The feelde of snowe / with the Egle blak ther ynne
Caught with the lymrode / colours as the glades
He brewe this cursednesse and al the synne
The wicked nest was wirker of thise nedes /
Nought lls phar / that ay toke goode hede
Of trouth and honour / but Armorek
Genylon Oliuer corrupt for mede
Broughtest this worthy kyng in soche a brek
¶ Worthy petir kynge of Cipre also
That Alisaunder wanne by his maistrie
To ful many an hethen / thou wroghtist woo
Of whiche thyne owne legis had envie
And for no thynge / but for thy chyualrie
They in thy bed han slayn the / by the morowe
Thus can fortune gerien and gye
But out of Ioie / brynge men unto sorowe /
¶ Of Meleyn grete Barnabo vescounte
God of delyte / and scourge of lumbardie
Whi shuld not / I thyn fortune acounte
Sithen in estate / thou clomben were so hye /
Thy Broder sone / that was thy double allie
For he thy neviwe was and sone in lawe
Withyn his prisou made the to die
And why ne howe wote I / that thou were slawe /
¶ Of the Erle Hugelyn / of pise the languour
Ther may no tunge telle for pyte
But litel out of pise stant a tour
In which tour in prison put was he
And with him / bene his litel childern three
The eldest scarsely v yere was of age
Allas /fortune it was grete crueltee
Such briddes forto putte in suche a cage
Dampned he was to deye in that prisou
For Rogger which that bisshop was of pyse
Hadde on him made a fals suggestiou
Thorgh whiche / the puple gan on hym aryse
And putt hym to prison in suche wyse
As ye han herde / and mete and drynke he hadde
So smal that it myght not suffise
And ther with al it was ful poor and badde /
And on a day bifelle þᵗat in that our
Whan that his mete / was wonte to be brought
The Gailler shitte the doores of the Tour
He herde it wel / but he segh it nought
And in his herte anon ther fille a thought
That they for hunger wold don hym dyen /
Allas quod he allas / that I was wrought
Therwith the teeres fille from his eyen /
His yonge Sone / that iij yere was of age
Vnto hym seide / Fader / whi do ye wepe /
Whan wil the Gailour / brynge oure potage
Is ther no mossel brede / that ye do kepe
I am so hungry / that I may not slepe
Nowe wolde god / that I myght slepen ever
Than shuld non hungyr in my wombe crepe
Ther nys no thyng / sauf brede / þᵗat me were lever
Thus day / by day / this childe gan crie
Til in his Faders barme adoun it lay
And seide fare wel / Fader I mote dye /
And kissed his Fader / and deide the same day
And whan that wooful Fadere that say
For woo his armes two he gan to byte
And seide allas fortune / and welaway
Thy fals whele my wo I may al wyte /
His Childern went that it for hunger was
That he his armes gnewe / and not for woo
And seide Fader / doith not so allas
But rather ete the flessh vppon vs twoo
Oure Flessh thou yaf vs / take it vs froo
And ete ynowe / right thus to hym they seide /
And after that withyn a day or twoo
They laide hem dou in his lappe / and deyde
Hym self despeired eke / for hunger starf
This ended this myghty Erle of pyse
From high astaat / fortune from hym karf
Of this traitorie / i ought ynowe suffise
Who so wil here it in a lenger wyse
Redeth the grete poete of ytaile .
for he can it devyse
From poynt / to poynt wolde wil he faille /
¶ Al though that Nero were as vicious
As eny fende / that lith ful low adou
Yet he as tellith vs Swethoneus
This wide worlde he hadde in subiecciou
Bothe Est and West and septēmtriou
Of Rubies Saphires / and of pierlys white
Were al his clothes browded vp and dou
For he in gemys gretely caught delyte /
More delicate / more pompous of aray
More proude was never Emꝑper/paroᵘur than he
That ilke cloth / that he had wered a day
After that tyme / he nolde it never see
Nettes of golde rere had he grete plente
To fissh in tyber / whan hym lust to pley
His lustes were as lowe in his degree
For fortune / as his frende wolde hym obeye
He Rome brent for his delycacie
The Senatours / he slowe vpon a day
To here how men / wolde wepe and crie
And slowe his Broder / and by his Sust̉er/re lay
His moder made he / in pitous aray
For he here wombe slitte to be holde
Wher he conseived was so welaway
That he so litel / of his Moder tolde /
No teere out of his eyen for that sight
Ne came / but saide a faire wōmman was she /
Grete wonder is / that he coughe or myght
Be domes man / of here dede bowte
The wyne to brynge cōmmaunded he
And drank a nou / nou other woo he made
Whan myght is Ioyned vnto crueltee
Allas to depe wil the venyme wade .
In youth a Maist̉er/re hadd this Emꝑper/parour
To theche hym lettrure and curtesie
For of moralite / he was the flour
As in his tyme / but if bokes lye
And whiles / his Maist̉er/re of hym hadde maistrye
He made hym so konnyng / and so souple
That longe tyme it was / or tyrannye
Or eny vice durst in hym vncouple /
This Seneca of which I devyse
By cause Nero hadde of hym such drede
For he for vices / wolde hym chastise
Discretly / as by word and nought by dede
Sir wolde he sein an Emꝑper/paroᵘur mote nede
Be vertuous / and hate tyrannye
For which he hym bath made to blede
On both his armes tyl he most die
This Nero hadde eke acustumance
In youth ayeinst his Maist̉er/re forto ryse
Which afterward hym thought a grete grevance
Therfore / he made hym dye in this wyse
But nathalees this Senec the wyse
Chees in bath to dye in this manere
Rather than in other turmentrie
And thus hath Nero slayn his Maist̉er/re dere
Nowe fille it so / that fortune lust noo lenger
The high pride of Nero to cherissh
For he was stronge / yet was he strenger
She thought thus by god I am to nyse
To sette a man / that is fulfilled in vyse
In hegh degree / and Emꝑper/paroᵘur hym calle
By god out of his Sete / I wil hym trise
Whan he leest weneth / sonnest shal he falle /
The puple roos vppon hym on a nyght
For his defaute / and when he it espied
Out of doors / anon he hath hym dight
Allon / and there he wend han bene alyed
He knocked fast / and ay the more he cried
The faster shitten they the doores alle
For drede of this hym thought that he dyed
And went his way no lenger dorst he calle
The puple cried / and rombled vp and dou
That with his eeres he herde / what they seide
Wher is this fals tyraunt this Nerou
For feer almost out of his witt he breide
And to his godes pytously / he preide
For socour / but it myght not betyde
For drede of this / hym thought that he deide
And ranne into a gardeyn / hym to hyde
And in this gardeyne founde he cherles twey
Sitteng by a fyre ful grete and rede
And to the Cherles twey / he gan to preie
To sleen hym / and to gerden of his hede
That to his body whan that he were dede
Were no dispite ydone / for his defame
Hym self he slough he couthe no better rede
Of which fortune logh and had goode game
¶ Was never Capteygne vnder a kynge
That regneth more in subiecciou
Ne stronger was / in feelde of all thynge
As in his tyme / ne gretter of renou
Ne more pompous in high psumpciou
Than Olyphern / which fortune ay kist
So lykerously / and ladde hym vp and dou
Til that he heded was / er that he wist
Nought oonly / that this world hadde of hym awe
For lesynge of rychesse and libtee
But he made euery man renye his lawe
Nabugodonosor was lorde seide he /
Noon other god shuld honoured be
Ayeinst his heest / no wight durst t̉er/respace /
Sauf in Bethulra a straunge Cite /
Wher Eliachim a prest was of that place
But take kepe of the deth of Olypherne /
Amyd his hooste he dronke lay on a nyght
Withyn his Tent large as is a barne
And yet for al his pompe and al his myght
Iudith a woman / as he lay vpright
Slepynge his hede of smote and fro his tent
Ful prevely she stale from eủer/rey wight
And into the Cite she is went
¶ What nedeth it of kyng Antiochus
To telle his highe and rial mageste
His highe pride his werkes venemous
For suche another nas never non as he
Redeth swiche that he was in Machabe
And redeth the proude worde that he seide
And why he feele / fro his ꝓprosperyte /
And in a hylle / howe wrecchedly he deide
Fortune hym had enchaunsed so in pride
That verely he wende he myght atteyne /
Vnto the sterres vppon euery syde /
And in a balaunce vnto ich mounteyne
And all the floodes of the see restreyne
And goddes puple had he most in hate
Hem wolde he slee / in torment or in peyne
Wenyng that god ne myght his pⁱride abate
And for that Nichanour and tymothee
With Iewes were venquysshed myghtely
Vnto the Iewes / suche an hate hadde he /
That he hadde greitheth his chare ful hastily
And swore and seide ful dispitously
Vnto Ierlm he wolde eftsone
To wrek his Ire on it ful cruelly
But of his pʳpos / he was lett fulsone
God for his manace / hym so sore smote
With vnvisible wounde ay vncurable
That in his guttes karf so and bote
That his peynes were importable
And certeynly / the wrecche was resonable
For mony mannys guttes did he peyne
But from his pʳpos cursed and dampnable
For alle his smerte he nolde hym nought restreyne
But bade anon / apparaillen his hoste
And sodeynly / or he was of it ware
God daunted al his pride / and al his boste
For he so soor falle out of his Chare
That hurt his lymes / and his skyn to tare
So that he ne myght goo / ne ryde
But in a chayer / men a boute hym bare
Al for brused bothe bak and syde /
The wrecche / of god hym smote so cruelly
That in his body wycked wormes crepe
And ther with al / he stonke so horrybly
That noon of all his meyne that hym kepte
Wheder that he woke / other ellis slepte /
Ne myght not the stynke / of hym endure
In this meschief he wayled and eke wepte
And knewe / god lord ouer eủer/rey creature /
To alle his hoste / and to hym self also
Ful latsom / was the stynk of his careyne
No man ne myght bere hym to ne fro
And in his stynke / and in his horryble peyne
He starf ful wrecchedly in a mounteyne
Thus hath this Robber / and this omycyde
That mony aman made to wepe / and pleyne
Suche guerdou as bilongeth vnto pryde
The story of Alisaundre is so cōmmune
To eủer/rey wight / that hat discreciou
Hath herde sumwhat / or al of his fortune
This wilde world / as in conclusiou
He wan by strenght / or by his renou
They weren glad / for pees vnto hym sendēm
The pride of man / and beeste he leide adou
Wher so he came / into the worldes ende /
Comꝑper/parisou ne myght never yet be made
Bytwixt hym / and another conquerour
For all this world for drede of hym quaked
He was of knyghthode / and of fredam flour
Fortune made hym / the heier of here honour
Save wyne / and wymen / no thyng myght him aswage
His hie entent in armes and labour
So was he ful of louyng corage /
What pite were it to hym þo I you tolde
Of armes / and C Mˢ moo
Of kynges princes and Erles bolde
Whiche he conquered / and brought hem into woo
I say as fer as man may ryde and goo
The world was his / what shuld I moor devyse
For though I wroot / and tolde you evermoo
Of his knyghthode / it myght not suffice /
Twelve yere / he reigned / as seith Machabe
Philippes Sone of Macedo he was
That first was kyng of Grece the the contre
O worthy gentil Alisaunder allas /
That ever shuld Falle such a caas to the
Enpoysened of thyne owne folk thou were
Thyn fortune hath torned to an asse quod he
And yet for the / she weepith never a teere
Whoo shal men yeve teeres to compleyn
The deth of gentilnesse / and of fraunchise
That the world welded in his demeyne
And yet hym thought / it myght not suffise
So ful was his corage / of his imprise
Allas who shal me helpe to indyte
Fals fortune and poisou to despise
The which twoo / of all this / woo I write
By wysdom manhode / and by labour
From humlehede / and from Royal mageste
Vp roos he Iulius the Conquerour
That all the Occident by londe / and eke by See
By strenght of hande / or ellis by trete
Vnto Rome / made hem tributarie
And sithens of Rome the Emꝑper/parur was he /
Til that fortune wex his Aduersarie /
O myghty Cesar / that in thessalye
Ayeinst pompeus Fader thyne in lawe
That of the Orient had al the chiualrye
As fer as that the day gynneth dawe
Thogh thorght thy knyghthode hast hem take and slawe
Sauf fewe folk / that with pompeus fledde
Thorgh which thou puttest / all the orient in awe
Thank fortune / that so wel it spedde /
But now a lytel while I wol bewayle
This pompeus / this noble Conquerour
Of Rome / which that fligh at this batayle /
I say oon of his men a fals traytour
His hede of smote to wynne hym fauour
Of Iulius / and to hym the hede he brought
Allas pompeye / of the Orient conquerour
That fortune vnto such a fyne the brought
To Rome ayein repaireth Iulius
With his triumphe laureate ful hie
But on a tyme Brutus Cassius
That ever hadde to his high estate envye /
Ful prively had made conspiracie
Ayenst this Iulius in ful subtile wyse
And cast the place / in whiche he shuld dye /
With boydekynnes / as I shal you devyse /
This Iulius to the Capitole he went
Vppon a day / as he was wonte to goon
And in the Capitole / anon he him hent
This fals Brutus / oon of his foule foon
And styked hym with boydekynnes Anoon
With mony a wounde / and thus they let hym lye
But never gronte he / at noo stroke but oon
Or ellis at twoo / but if the story lie /
So manly was this Iulius of herte
And so wel loued his ostatly honeste
And though his deedly woundes so soore smerte
His mantel over his hippes cast he
For no man shuld se his privete /
And as he lay on deynge in a traunce
And wist verreley that dede was he
Of honeste yet hadde he / remembrance /
Lucane to this storie I recōmmende /
And to Swetou and to Valerius also /
That of his storie writeth worde and ende
How that these grete conquerous twoo
Fortune was first frende / and sithen a foo
No man me trest vppon his favour longe
But have hur in a wayte foreủer/remoo
Witnesse on alle thise Conquerours stronge
¶ This riche Cresus / whilom kynge of luyde
Of whiche Cresus / Cyquus sore hym dradde
Yet was he kaught amyddes all al his pride
And to be brent / men to the fyre hym ladde
But suche areyn doun from the walken shadde
And slekked the fyre / and made hym to eskape
But to be ware / yet no gᵃce he hadde
Tyl fortune on the galous made hym gape /
Whan he escaped was / he kuoth not stynte
Forto bygynne / to regne newe ayein /
He wende wel for that fortune hym sente
Suche happe / that he escaped thorgh the reyn
That of his foos / he myght not be sleyn
And suche a sweven vppon a nyght he mette
Of whiche he was so proude and eke feyne
That in /vengeance he all his hert sette
Vppon a tree he was / that as hym thought
Ther Iubit̉er/re hym wassh both hals and side
And phebus eke / a faire towell hym brought
To drye hym wᵗith / and therfore wex his preide
And to his doughter that stood hym beside
Which that he knewe in hegh sentence habounde
He badd hire / telle hym / what it signifieth
And she his dremes bygan right thus expounde /
The tree quod she the galuous is to mene /
And Iubit̉er/re bytokeneth snowe and rayne /
And phebus / with his toweil so clenene
To bene the sonne stremes to seyne
Thou shalt anhanged be Fader certayne
Rayne shal the wassh / and sone shal the drye
Thus warned she hym / ful plat and ful playne
This doughter / that called was phanye /
An hounged was Cresus / the proude kynge
His Roial trone myght hym not avayle
Tregedie nys non other man thynge
Ne can in synnynge crie ne bewaille
But that Fortune alwey wil assaile
With Vnwar strokes / the regnes that bene proude
For whan men trusten hure / than wil she faille /
kouer her bright face / with a cloude /
Here eendeth the monkes tale /
¶ Of The prologe of the Nonne prest hereys the bygynneng
Lo sire quod the knyght goode ʆser/sir no more of this
That ye han seide / ys right ynowe ywys
And mochel more / for lytel heuynesse
Is right ynowe / to mochel folk I gesse
I say for me / it is a grete dissese
Wheer as men han be in grete welthe and eese /
To here of here sodeyn falle allas /
And the contrʳie is Ioie / and grete solas
And whan a man hath be in poor estaat
And clymbeth vp / and wexeth fortunate
And there abideth in prosꝑper/paritee /
Suche thyng is gladsom as it thenkyth me
And though such thyng were goodely for to telle
Ye / quod oure hoost / by seynt Pavles belle
Ye saie right saith / this monke he clappeth loude
He spak / how fortune coủer/reed with a cloude
I noot never what / and also of a tregedye
Right nowe ye herde / and ꝑper/parde no remedie
It is forto be wailled / ne compleyne /
That þᵗat is don / and als it is a peyne
And ye have saide to here of heuynesse
Sir monke no more of this / so god you blesse
Your tale ennoyeth al this companye
Suche talkynge / it is not worth a boterflie
For theyr is no disport ne game
Wherfore ʆser/sir Monke / Daune Piers by youre name
I prey you hertely / telle vs sumwhat ellys
For seker ne chynkyng of youre bellys
That on youre brydell hongen in euery syde /
By hevene kyng / that for vs all deyde /
I shal for this falle doun for slepe
Al though the snowe hadde never be so depe
Than hadde youre tale bene told in veyne
For certeinly / as these clerkes seyne
Where as a man may have noon audience
Nought helpith to tellen his sentence /
And wel I wote / the substance is in me
If eny thyng / shal wel reported be /¶/
div.fw: ¶ The tale of the Nonne Prest /
div.l: Sir seith sumwhat / of huntyng I you preye
Nay quod the Monke I have no lust to pleye
Now lat a nother telle / as I have tolde
Than spoke oure hoost / with rude speche an bolde
And seide vnto the Nonnes Preest anoon
Come neer ʆser/sir Preest / come heder ʆser/sir Iohn
Telle vs suche thynges / as may oure hertes glade
Be mery though thou ryde vppon a Iade
What though thy hors be foule and lene
So he wil ʆser/sirue the / rek not a bene /
Loke that thyn herte be mery eủer/remoo
Yis Hoost / quod he / so mote I ryde or goo
But I be mery I wis I wil be blamed
And right a noon / he hath his tale tamed
And thus he seide / to vs euerychon
This swete preest / this good ʆser/sir Iohn /
¶ Here endeth the Prologe of the Nonne preest his tale
¶ And here bygynneth the same preest his tale /
A poor wydowe somdele stoupe in age
Whilom was dwellyng in a narowe cotage
Bisides a grove stondyng in a dale
This widowe of which I tolde you my tale
Sithens thilke day / that she was last a wiff
In paciens lad a full symple lyff
For litel was here catell / and here rent
By husbondrye / of such / as god her sent
She fande here self / and eke here doughtren twoo .
Thre large Sowes / had she / and noo moo .
Thre kyen and a shepe / that hight Malle
Ful slutty was here bour / and eke hure halle
In whiche she ete mony a slender mele
Of poynant sauce / hire nedith never a dele
No deynte morsell passed here drote /
Hire diete was accordant to here Cote
Repliciou ne made hire never seke /¶T
A temper diete / was al hire phisike
And excersice and hertes suffisaunce
The govte let here no thyng to daunce
Ne ꝑper/parplexite ne shent not here hede
Ne wyne drank she / neither whyte ne rede
Her borde was ʆser/sirued / most wᵗith white and blak
Milke and brovne bred / in whiche she founde no lak
Seyned bacou / and sumtyme an eye or tweye
For she was / as it were a maner deye /
A gardeyne she hadde enclosed al aboute
With stykkes / and a drie diche wᵗith oute /
In whiche she hadde a cok / that hight Chaunteler
In al the lande / of crowyng was noon his pere
His vois was meryer / than the mery organ /
On masse daies / that in the Churche goon
More siker was his crowyng in his langage
Than is a clokke / or eny Abbey Orlage
By nature he knewe ech assenciou
Of Equynoxial of thik toun
For whan degrees xv / were descended
Than knewe he / that it not be amended
Hes combe was redder / than the fyne corall
And batailled / as it were a castell wall
Leke azure were his legges / and his toon
His byl blak / and as the Iete it shon
His nayles whitter / than the lyle floure
And lyke burnysshed gold was his coloure /
¶ This gentil Cok / had in his goủer/renance
Vij / hennes for to doon hym plesaunce
Whiche were his Sust̉er/res / and his ꝑper/paramoᵘurs
And wonder like to hym / as of colours
Of whiche the fairest hued vnder throte
Was cleped faire Damysel ꝐPer/Partelote
Curteis she was discreet / and debonair
And companable / and bere her self so faire
Sithen thilk day / that she was vij / nyght olde
That trewely / she hath the herte in holde
Of Chaunteler / loken in euery lith / ¶
He loved hire so that wel was hym therwith
But suche a Ioie as it was to here hym synge
Whan that the bright sonne ganto sprynge
In swete accord / my leef is fare in lande
For thilke tyme / as I have vnderstande
Beestes and briddes couthe speke and synge
And so bifelle / that in a dawynge
As Chaunteler / amonge his wyves alle
Sat on his perche / that was in the halle
And next hym sat this faire ꝐPer/Partelote
This Chauntelere gan gronen in his throte
As a man / that in dreme is drecched sore
And whan that ꝑper/partelote this herde hym rore
She was a gast / and seide herte dere
What eileth you / to grone in this manere
Ye bene a verrey sleper / fy for shame
And he / answered / and seide this ma Dame
I praye you / that ye take it to no greef
By god I mette / that I was in such mescheef
Right now / that yet myn hert is sore afright
Nowe quod he / my sweven rede aright
And kepe my body out of foule prisou
Me mette / that I ronne vp and dou
Withyn oure yerde / wher as I seghe a beest
Was like an hounde / and wolde haue made areest .
Vppon my body / and wolde haue had me deed
His colour was bitwixt white / and reed
And tipped was his taile / and bothe his eeres
With blak vnlyke the remenᵃnte of his heeres /
His snowte smal with glouynge eyen twey
Yet of his look for fere almost I dey
This caused me my gronyng douteles
A voy quod she / fy on you herteles
Allas quod she for by that god above
Nowe han ye lost my hert and my love /
I can not loue a couard / by my faith
For certes / what so eny woman seith
We alle desiren / if it myght bee ¶/
To han husbondes / hardy wise and free
And secre / ne no Nygard / ne no fool
Ne hym that is a gast of euery tool
Ne non avauntoᵘur / by that god above
How dorst ye saie so for shame vnto youre love
That any myght make you a ferde
Have ye noo mannes hert / and han a berde
Allas and con ye bene agast of swevens
Swevens engendren of Replexions
Whan humours bene to habundant in a wight
Certes this dreme / which ye han dremed to nyght
Cometh of to moche suꝑper/parfluite
Of youre Colre rede parde
Which causeth folk to dremen here dremes
Of arous and of fuyre with the rede lemes
Of rede beestes / that wil hem byte
Of Contekes of whelpes grete and lyte
Right as the humoᵘur malencolye
Causeth mony aman in slepe to crie
For fere of Boles / and beres blake /
Or ellis blake devels wil hem take
Of other humoᵘurs couth I telle also
That worchen many a man in slepe wo
But I wil telle as lightly as I can
Lo Catou which / that was so wise aman
Seide he not thus / ne yeve ye no force of dremes
Now ʆser/sir quod she whan we flee from the bemes
For godes love / as taketh some laxatif
Vpperile of my soule / and of my lyf
I counseill you the beste / I wil not lye
That bothe of colre / and of malyncolye
Ye purge you / and for ye shul not tarie
Tho that in this towne nys noon apotacarie
I shal my self to herbes tochen you /
That shal be youre helthe / and youre prou /
And in the gardeyne / tho herbes shal I fynde
The which han of here ꝓpropertee be kynde
To purgen you / bynethen / and eke above ¶
Foryeteth not this / for godes owne love
Ye bene ful colrike of complexiou
Wher the sunne in his Ascenciou
Ne fynde you replete / of youre humoᵘurs hoote
And if it do / I dar wel lay a grote
That ye shul have a fever tercian
Or an anger / that may be youre ban
A day or two / ye shul have degestyves
Of wormes / or ye take youre laxatives
Of lawreole Centorie / and of fimytere
Or ellis of Ellibere / that groueth there
Of Capatuse / or of Gaitres buries
Of herbe Ive / groueng in youre gardeyne þ̉er/re mery is
Pykke hem vp / as they growe / and ete hem Inne
Be mery husbond / for youre Faders kynne
Dredeth no dreme / I can saie you no more
Ma Dame / quod he / gramercy of youre lore
But nathalees / as touchyng to Catou
That hath of wisdom such discreciou
By god men may in olde bokes rede
That god is good counsell at nede
Of mony aman moor of auctorite
That ever Catou was so mot I the
That al the revers seyne / of this sentence
And han wel founden by experience
That dremes bene significacions
As wel of Ioie / as of tribulacions
That folke enduren / in this lyf psent
It nedeth not to make of this noon argument
The verrey preef sheweth it in dede
Oon of the grattest auctour / that men of rede
Seith thus / whilom two felawes went
On pilgrimage / in a ful goode intent
And happed so / they comen in a toun
Wher as ther was suche congregaciou
Of puple / and eke of streit herbegage
That they ne founde / as moche as a cotage
In whiche / they bothe myght ylogged be ¶
Wherfore they mosten of necessite
And for that nyght departen of companye
And eche of hem / goth vnto his hosterie
And toke his loggeng / as it wolde falle
That oon of hem / was logged in a stalle
Ferre in ayerde / with Oxen of the plowe
That other man was logged wel ynowe
And as was his aventure / and his fortune
That vs goủer/reneth alle / as in comune
And so bifelle longe er it were day
This man mette in his bedde ther as he lay
How that his felowe gan on hym calle
And seide allas for in anoxes stalle
This nyght shal I be mordred þ̉er/re I lye
Now helpe me dere Brother or I dye /
In al haste come he to me / he seyde
This man out of his slepe / for fere abreyde
And whan he was waket out of his slepe
And turned hym / and toke of this noo kepe
Hym thought his dreem was but vanyte
Thus twies in his slepyng dremed he
But at the thred tyme yet his felowe
Came as hym thought / I am nowe yslawe
Byholde my blody woundes depe and wyde /
Aryse vp erly in the morn tyde
And at the west gate of the towne quod he
A Cart ful of dunge / ther thou shalt see
In which my body is hid ful priuely
Do thilk carte aresten bodely
My gold caused my morder soth to seyn
And tolde hym euery point / how he was slayn
With a ful pitous face pale of hewe
And trest wel / his dreme he founde ful trewe
For on the morowe / as sone as it was daye
To his felowes Inne / he toke the way
And whan he came / to this Oxes stalle
After his felowe / he bigan to calle
The hostiler answered to hym a non ¶
And seide ʆser/sir / youre felawe ys gon
As sone / as day he went out of the tou
This man gan falle in grete suspectiou
Remembrynge onto his dremes that he mette
And forth he goth / no lenger nolde he lette
Vnto the west gate / of the towne and founde
A dunge Cart / as he went to dunge the londe
That was araied in the same wyse /
As ye han herde / the dede man devyse /
And with an hardy hert he gan to crie
Vengeance / and Iustice of felonye /
My felowe ymordred is / this same nyght
And in this Cart he lith gapyng vpright
The dede man that murdred was al newe
O blesful god / that art so iust and trewe
Lo hou thou bywriest morder alwaie
Murdre wil out / that se we / day by daie
Murdre is so wratsom / and abhomynable
To god / that is iust and so resonable
That he ne wol not suffre hilled be
They it abide / a yere or twoo or thre
Murdre wil out / this ys my conclusiou
And right a noon Mynystres of the towne
Han hent the Carter / and soor hym pyned
And eke the hostiler / so fer engyned
That they biknewe hire wickednesse anon
And weren honged / by the nek bon
Here may men see / that dremes bene to drede
And certes in the same boke I rede
Right in the next Chapitre aft̉er/re this
I gabbe not so have I oye and blis
¶ Two men that wolden han passed the see
For certein cause / into a fer contree
Yf that the wynde ne hadde be contᵃrie
That made hem in a Cite forto tarie
That stode ful mery vppon an haven side
But on a day ayeinst the even tyde
The wynde gan chaunge / and blowe as hym lest ¶/
Ioly and glad / they wenten vnto rest
And casten hem ful erly forto saille
But herken that oo man fille in grete peralle
That on of hem / in slepyng as he lay
Hym mette a wonder dreme ayeinst the day
Hym thought a man stode by his beddes syde
And hym cōmmaunded / that he shulde a byde
And seide hym thus / if thou to morowe wende
Thou shalt be dreint / my tale is at an ende
¶ He awook and tolde his Felawe / what he mette
And praied hym / his viage for to lette
As for that daie / he praide hym to a bide
His Felawe / that laie by his beddes side
Gan forto laugh / and scorned hym ful faste
Noe dreme quod he / may my hert agaste
That I wil lett for to do my thyngges
I sette not a stawe by dremyngges
For swevens be but vanytees and Iapes
Men dreem alway of owels and o apes
And of many amase ther with all
Men dremen of thynges / that never was ne shall
But sith I see / that thou wolt here abide
And thus forslowthen wilfully the tyde /
God wote it reweth me / and now have good day
And thus he toke his leve / and went his way
And er that he had half his cours assailled
But I not why / ne what meschaunce it eiled
But casuelly the shippes botme rent
And shipp and man vnder the water went
In sight of other shippes hym beside
That wᵗith hym seilled / at the same tyde /
And therfore seide ꝑper/partelote so dere
By suche ensamples olde / maist thou here
That no man shulde be to rechelees
Of dremes for I seie the / doutelees
That mony a dreme / ful soor is for to drede
Lo in the lyf of seynt kenelme I rede
That was kenulphes sone / the noble kyng ¶
Of Martenrike howe kenelme mette a thynge
A litel er he was mordred on a day
His Moder in avisiou he say
His norice hym expouned every dele
His sweven / and bad hym / for to kepe hym wele
For tresou / but he was vij yere olde
And therfore lytel heed hath he tolde
Of eny dreme / so holly was his herte
By god I had lever than my sherte
That ye had herde his legende as have I
Dame ꝑper/partilote I seye you trewely /
Macrobius that writ the avisiou
In Affrik / of the worthi Cipriou
Affermeth dremes / and seith that ther bene
Warneng of thynges / that men after sene /
And furthermore I pᵃy you loketh well
The olde testament of Danyell
If he heelde dremes of eny vanyte
Rede eke of Ioseph / and ye shul see
Wheder dremes / somtyme I seie not alle
Warnynge of thynges bene / that shul after falle
Loke of Egipt / the kyng Daun pharo
His baker / and his botiller also /
Wher they ne felt non effect in dremes
Who so wolde seche the actes of sondry remes
May rede of dremes mony a wonder thynge
Lo Cresus / whiche was of lyde kynge
Mette he not / that he sett vppon a tree
Whiche signified / he shulde an hounged be /
¶ Lo here Adromacha Ectours wyf
That day / that Ector shulde lese his lyf
She dremed on the same nyght biforn
How that the lyf of Ector shuld be lorn
If thilke day he went into bataille
She warned hym / but it myght not availle
He went forto fyghten neuer the lees
But he was slayn at Achilles
But thilke tale is alto longe to telle ¶
And eke it is nyght day I may not dwelle
Shortely I sey as for a conclusiou
That I shal have / at this avisiou
Of aduersitees / and I sey furthermore
That I nyl telle of laxatifs noo store
For thoo bene venymous / I wote right wel
I hem defie / I love hem never a dele
Now lat vs speke of myrth and stynt al this
Ma Dame ꝐPer/Partelote / so have I blis
Of oo thynge god hath sende me large gᵃce
For whan I se the bewte of youre face
Ye bene so scarlet / rede aboute the eyen
It makith al my drede forto dyen
For also siker / as In principio
Mulier est hominis confusio
Ma Dame / the sentence of this latyn is
Wōmman is manes Ioie / and al his blis
For whan I fele youre soft syde
Al be it so that I may you not ryde
For that the perche is made so narowe allas
I am so ful of Ioie / and of solas
That I defie both sweven and dreme
And with that worde / he flegh dou from the beme
For it was day / and eke his hennes all
And with a chuk / he gan hem forto call
For he had founde a corn lay in the yerde
Ryal he was / and noo more a ferde
He fethered ꝑper/partelote xxᵗⁱ tyme
And tred as oft er it was prime
He loketh as it were a grym lyou
And on his toos / he romed vp and dou
Hym deyned not / to sett his feet on grounde
Ay clokked he / whan he hadd a corn founde
And to hym / than ranne his wifes alle /
Thus roial as a prince in his halle
Leve I this Chaunteler in his pasture
And after wil I telle of his aduenture
Whan the monthe in which the world bygon ¶
That hight Marche / whan god first made mon
Was complete / and passed were also
Sythen Marche bygan xxx daies and twoo
Bifelle that Chaunteler in his pride
His seven wyfes walkyng hym bysyde
Cast vp his eyen / to the bright sonne
That in the signe of Taurus was yronne
Xxxᵗⁱ degres and oon / and sum what more
He knewe by kynde / and by noon other lore
That it was pryme / and crewe wᵗith blisful stevene
The sonne he seide / is clomben vp to hevene
Xl degrees and oon and moo ywys
Ma Dame ꝐPer/Partelote / my worldes blis
Herken hou / thise blesful briddes synge
And se the fressh floures hou they sprynge
Ful is my herte of revell / and solace
But sodeynly hem felle a sorifull cace /
For ever the latter ende of Ioie / is sone agoo /
And comely oft tyme it falleth soo .
And if Arthour couthe faire endite
He in a cronycle myght savely write
As for a soueraigne notabilite
Nowe euery wyse man herken me /
This story is also trewe I vndertake
As is the boke of Launcelot the lake
That wōmmen heelde in ful grete reuerence
Now wil I turne ayein into my sentence
A koll Fox ful of sleght / and inyquyte
That in the Groue had woned yeres three
By high ymagynaciou aforn cast
The same nyght / throwgh out the hegges brast
Into the yerde / there Chaunteler / the faire
Was wonte / and eke his wifes to repaire
And a bedde of wortes stylle he laye /
Tyl it was passed vndron of the daye
Waytynge his tyme / en Chaunteler to falle
As gladly done thise homycydes alle
That yn a wayte ligge / to mordre men ¶
O fals mordoᵘur lyggynge in thy den /
O newe Scariot / and newe Genylou
Fals dissimyloᵘur / O greek Cynou
That broughtest Troie al vtterly to sorowe
O Chauntelere acursed be that morowe
That thou into the yerde / fleghe from the beemes /
Thou were full wel ywarned by thy dremes
That ilke aday was ꝑper/parilous to thee
But that god wote / afore mote nedes bee /
After the oppynyou of certeyne clerkes
Witnesse on hym / that eny clerk is /
That in scole grete Altercaciou
In this mater / and grete disputaciou
And hath bene of an C Mˢ men /
But I ne can bulte it to the brenne
As can the holy doctoᵘur Augustyne
Or Boece / or the bisshopp Bradwardyne
Whedere / that goddes wille afore wytynge
Streyneth me nedely forto don a thynge
Nedly clepe I symple necessite
Or ellis yif the free choise be gᵃunted me
To do that same thynge / or to do it noght
Thought god forwote it er it were wrought
Or of his wepynge streyneth never a dele
But by necessite condycionell
I wil not have to doon of such matere /
My tale is of a Cok / as he shul after here
That toke his counseill / of his wif with sorowe
To walken in the yerde / vppon the morowe
That he had mette the dreme / that I you tolde
Wommens counsell is often colde /
Wōmmans counsell brought vs first to woo
And made Adam from ꝑper/paradise to go /
Ther as he was ful mery and wel at eese /
For I not whom I myght displese /
If I wōmmans counseill wold blame
Passe ouer / for I seide it on my game ¶
Rede Auctoᵘurs / where they trete of such matere
And what they seien of wommen here
Thise bene the Cokkes wordes / and not myne
I can noo harme of wommen devyne
Fair in the sande to bath hir myryly
Lith ꝐPer/Partelote / and all here Sust̉er/res here by
Ayeinst the sōmne / and Chaunteler so free
Sange merier / than the mermayde in the see /
For phisialogus seith witterly
How that they syngen wel and myrily
And so byfelle as he cast his eye
Amonge the wortes vppon a boterfleye
He was ware of this / for that laie ful lowe
No thynge ne lust hym than forto crowe /
But cried a non kok kok / and vp he sterte
As a man that was affraied in herte
For naturelly a beest desireth to flee
For his contrarie if he may it see
Ther he it never had sey it erst wᵗith eye
This Chaunteler / whan gan he / hym espie
He wolde han fledde / but that the Fox anon
Seide gentil ʆser/sir allas what wil ye don
Bene ye affraied of me / that am youre frende
Certes ʆser/sir than bene ye vnhende
If I to you wolde harme or velenye
I am not come youre counsell to aspye
But trewely the cause of my comynge
Was only to herken / how that ye synge
For sothly ye han as mery a stevene
As angel hath / that is in hevene
Ther with ye han in musyke more felynge
That had Boys / or any that can synge
My lorde youre Fader / god his soule blesse
And eke youre Moder / of here gentilnesse
Han in my hous bene to you grete eese
And certes ʆser/sir right fayne wolde I you pleese
But for men speken of syngyng I wolde seyne
So mote I brouke myn eyen tweyne /¶/
Save ye / I ne herde never man so synge
As dede youre Fader in the mornynge
Certes it was of herte / al that he sange
And forto make his vois / the more strange
He wolde so peyne hym / that wᵗith his both eyen
He most wynke / so loude he dede cryen
And stonden on his tiptos therwith all
And strecth forth his neke longe and small
And eke he was of such discreciou
That ther nas no man in noo regiou
That hym outsonge / or of wysdam myght passe
I have wel redde Daun Bornel þ̉er/reasse
Amonge his v̉er/rese ther was a boke Cok
For a prestes sone / yaf hym a knok
Vppon his legges / while he was yonge and nyce
He made hym forto lese his benefice
But certeyn ther nys no comparisou
Bitwix the wisdam and discreciou
Of youre fader / and of his subtilite
Nowe syngeth ʆser/sir for seynt Charitee /
Lat see / conne ye youre fader countrefete
This Chaunteler / his wynges gan to bete
As man that coude his tresou not espie
So was he rauisshed with his flaterie
Allas ye lordes mony a fals fautoure
Ys in youre court / and mony losengeoure
That plesen you more / by my feith
Than he that sothfastnesse to you seith
Redeth Ecclesiastre of flaterie
Beth ware ye lordes of her trecherie
This Caunteler stood hye vppon his toos
Strecchynge his nek / and helde his eyen cloos
And gan to crowe loude for the nones
And daun Russel stert vp al at ones
And by the gargate hent Chaunteler
And on his bak toward the wode hym bere
For yet was ther no man hym sewed
O destene / that maist not bene eschewed ¶
Allas that Chauntelere fel fro the bemes
Allas his wif ne rought not of dremes
And on a fryday fel al this meschance
O Venus / that art goddes of plesance
Sithens that thy ʆser/siruᵃnt was this Chauntelere
And in thy ʆser/siruice did al his powere /
More for delyte / than the world to multiplie
Why woldest thou suffre on thy day to dye
O gaufrede / dere Maist̉er/re souereyne
That whan thy worthy kynge Richard was slayne
With shotte compleyndest his deeth so sore
Why ne hadde I nowe thy sentence and thy lore
The fryday forto chide as did ȝe
For on afriday shortely slayn was he
Than wolde I shewe you / how that I kouth pleyn
For Chaunteler / and for his peyne /
Certes suche crie ne lamentaciou
Was of ladies make whan yleou
Was wonne / and Pirris with his strenght suerde
Whan he hent kynge priam by the berde
And slowe hym as seide Ovidos
As maden all the hennes in the cloos
Whan they had seen of Chauntelere the sight
But soueraynly Dame ꝐPer/Partelote shright
Moche ludder / than did asdrebaldus wif
Whan that here husbond had lost his lyf
And that the Roymeynes / had brent Cartage
She was so ful of turment and of Rage
That wilfully into the fire she sterte
And brent here self with a stedefast herte /
O woofull hennes right so cried ye /
As whan Nero brent the Cite
Of Rome / criden the Senatours wyves
For that here husbondes shulde lese her lyves
Withoute gilt Nero hath hem slayn
Nowe wil I turne vnto my tale agayn
This sely widowe / and here doghters twoo
Herden the hennes crien / and maken woo . ¶
And out at the dore sterten they anon
And seght the Fox toward the grove gon
And bere on his bak the Cok away
They cried out harrowe / and welaway
A ha the Fox / and after hym they ran
And eke with staves mony another man
Ranne Col oure dog / talbot and garland
And Malkyn with here dystaf in here hande
Ranne Cowe and calf / and eke the verrey hogges
Soore a ferde for berkyng of the dogges
And showtyng of men / and of women eke
They ronne / so here hertes / hem thought to breke
They yeden as fendes done in helle
The dokes cried / as men wolde hem quelle
Out of the heves came the swarme of Bees
The gees for fere flowen over the trees
So hidous was the noise o benedicite
Certes he Iak strawe / and his meyne
Made never showtes / half so shrille
Whan that they wold eny flemmyng kylle
As that ilk day / was made vppon the Fox
Of bras they brought bemes and of box
Of horn / of bone / in which they povped
And therwith al / they shriked and shovted
It semed as that heven shulde falle
Nowe good men / I pᵃy you / herkeneth alle
Lo hou fortune turneth sodeynlye
The hope / and eke pⁱride of her envye
This Cok that lay vppon this Foxes bak
In al this drede / vnto the Foxe spak
And seide ʆser/sir if I were as ye
Ye shulde / I say as wys god helpe me
Turneth ayein / ye proude cherles all
A verrey pestilence / vppon you fall
Now am I come vnto this wode side
Mavgre youre hede the Cok shal here abide
I wil hym eete / in feith / and that anon
The cok answered in feith it shal be don ¶
And he spak that worde al sodeynly
This Cok broke from his mouthe delyuerly
And heghe vppon a tree / he flegh anon
And whan the Fox segh / that he was gon
Allas quod he / O Chaunteler allas
I have / quod he / don to you a trespas
In as moche as I made you aferde
Whan I you hent / and brought out of the yerde
But ʆser/sir I dede it in no wicked intent
Come doun / and I shal telle you what I ment
I shal say soth / god helpe me so
Nay than / quod he / I shrewe vs both twoo /
And first I shrewe my self bothe blood and bones
If thou bygile me / ofter than ones /
Thou shalt noo more / with thi Flaterie
Do me to synge / and wynke with myn eye
For he that wynketh / whan he shuld see
As wisly / god let hym / never thee /
Nay / quod the Fox / god yeve hym ameschance
That is so vndiscrete of gouernance
That Iangeleth / whan he shulde have pees
Lo suche it is / forto be rechelees
And negligent / and tristeth on flaterie
But ye that holde / this tale a folie
As of a Fox / and of a cok and an hene
Taketh the moralite / goode mene
For seynt Paule seith / al that writen is
To oure doctryne / it is iwreten ywis .
Taketh the fruyte / and lat the chaf be stille
Now good god / if that it be thy wille
As seith my lorde / so make vs alle good men
And brynge vs all / to his high blisse Amen .

¶ Here endeth the manciples tale / ¶ And here bygynneth
the prologe of the persone /
By that the manciple had his tale ended
The sonne from the south syde is descended
So lowe / that he was not to my sight
Degrees xxix as of hight
Ten of the clok / it was / so as I gysse
For xj foote / a lytel more or lesse
My shadowe was / at thilk tyme as there
Of suche fete / as my lengthe parted were
In vj fete equall of ꝓproporciou
Therwith the mones exaltaciou
I mene libra / alway gan assende
As we were entryng / at a thorpes ende
Wher with oure hoost / as he was wont to gye
As in this caas oure Ioly companye /
Seide in this wise / lordinges euerichon ¶
Now lacketh vs / noo tale moore than on
Fulfilled is my sentence / and my degree
At that forsoith it lekith mee
Almost fulfilled is myn ordinance
I pᵃy to god / so yeve hym / right good chaunce
That telleth vs a tale lustely
Sir prest quod he / art thou a Vicary
Or art thou a ꝑper/parsone / sey soth by thy fey
Be what thou be / ne breke not oure pley
For euery man / sauf thou hath tolde his tale
Vnbokel / and shewe vs what is in thy male
For trewely me thenketh by thy chere
Thou shuldest knet vp wel a grete matere
Telle vs a fable / anon for cokkes bones
This ꝑper/parsone answered / al atones
Thou getest fable noon ytolde for me
For poule / that writeth vnto Thimothe
Repreved hem / that wayuen sothfastnesse
And tellen fables / and suche wrecchednesse
Why shuld I sawe draf out of my feste
Whan that I may sawe whete / if that me leste
For which I say / if that ye lust to here
Moralite / and vertuous matere
And then that ye wol yeve me audience
I wil ful fayn / at Cristes reuerence
Done you plesance leeful as I can
But trusteth wel / I am a Sotheren man
I can not geest / rum / ram / ruf by letter
Ne god wote / ryme holde I / but lytel better
And therfore if you lust / I wol not glose
I wil you telle / amery tale in prose
To knyt vp al this feest / and make an ende
And Ihu for his gᵃce wit me sende
To shewe you the way / in this viage
Of thilk perfit glorious pilgrimage
That hight Iherusalem celestial
And yef ye vouchesauf / anon / I shal /
Bygynne vppon my tale / for whiche I preye /¶ꝐPer/Par/
Telle youre avise / I can no better seie /
But nathalees / this meditaciou
I putte it ay vnder correcciou
Of Clerkes / for I am nott text wel
I take but the sentence trusteth wel
Therfore I make protestaciou
That I wil stande to correcciou
Vppon this worde / we han assented sone
For as it semed / it was forto don
To ende in sōmme vertuos sentence
And forto yeve hym space and audience
And bedde oure hoste / he shuld to hym seye
That all we / to tellen his tale / hym preye /
Our hoste had the wordes for vs alle
Sir preste quod he / nowe faire mote you byfalle
Sey what you lust / and we shul gladly here
And with that word he saide in this manere
Telleth quod he youre meditaciou
But hasteth you / the sonn wil adou
Both fructuous / and that in lytel space
And to do wel / god sende you his grace /

¶ Here endeth the prologe / of the ꝑper/parsones tale / ¶ And
here bygynneth the tale of the person /

div.ab: (base) Here bigynneth the Persons tale

(base) Iere 6ᵒ State super vias et videte et interrogate de semitis
antiquis que sit via bona et ambulate in ea et inuenietis refrigerium animabus vestris et cetera

(base) Ovre swete lord god of heuene that no man wole
perisse but wole that we comen alle to the kNoweliche
of hym and to the blisful lyf that is pardurable
(base) amonesteth vs by the prophete Ieromie that seith in this wise

(base) Stondeth vp on the weyes and seeth and axeth of olde pathes that is to seyn of olde sentences which is the goode
wey
(base) and walketh in that wey and ye shal fynde refresshynge for youre soules et cetera

(base) Manye been the weyes espirituels that leden folk to oure lord Ihesu crist and to the regne
of glorie

(base) of whiche weyes ther is a ful noble wey and
a ful couenable which may nat faile to man ne to womman that thurgh synne hath mysgoon fro the righte wey
of Ierusalem celestial

(base) and this wey is clepid Penitence
of which men sholde gladly herknen and enquere with al
his herte

(base) to wite what is penitence and whennes

it is
clepid penitence and in how manye maneres been the accions
or werkynges of penitence

(base) and how manye spices ther
ben of penitences and whiche thynges apertenen and bihouen to penitence whiche thynges destourben penitence

(base) Seint Ambrose seith that penitence is the pleynynge of
man for the gilt that he hath doon and namoore to doon
any thyng for which hym oghte to pleyne

(base) And som dectour seith Penitence is the waymentynge of man that sorweth for his synne and pyneth hym self for he hath
mysdoon

(base) Penitence with certeyne circumstances is verray
repentance of a man that halt hym self in sorwe and oother
peyne for hise giltes

(base) and for he shal be verray penitent
he shal first biwailen the synnes that he hath doon and
stedefastly purposen in his herte to haue shrift of mouthe
and to doon satisfaccioun

(base) and neuere to doon thyng for which
hym oghte moore to biwaile or to compleyne and to continue in goode werkes or ellis his repentance may nat auayle

(base) For as seith Seint Isydre he is a Iapere and a gabbere and
no verray repentant that eft soone dooth thyng for which hym
oghte repente

(base) wepynge and nat for to stynte to do synne
may nat auaile

(base) But nathelees men shal hope that at euery
tyme that man falleth be it neuer so ofte that he may arise thurgh
penitence if he haue grace but certeynly it is greet dowithe

(base) for
as seith Seint Gregorie vnnethe ariseth he out of his synne
that is charged with the charge of yuel vsage

(base) and ther fore
repentant folk that stynte for to synne and forlete synne er that

(base) and he that synneth and verraily repenteth hym in his laste

lord Ihesu crist for his repentance but taak the siker wey

(base) and
Now sith that I haue declared yow what thyng is penitence
Now shul ye vnderstonde that ther been iij accions of penitence
(base) The firste is that if a man be baptised after that he hath synned

(base) Seint
Augustyn seith but he be penitent for his olde synful lyf he may
nat bigynne the newe clene lyf

(base) for certes if he be baptised with
oute penitence of his olde gilt he receyueth the mark of baptesme but nat the grace ne the remissioun of hise synnes til he haue repentance verray

(base) Another defaute

is this that men doon
deedly synne after that they han receyued baptesme

(base) The

(base) ther of seith Seint Augustyn
That penitence of goode and of humble folk is the penitence
of euery day

(base) The speces of penaunce been iij that oon of
hem is solempne Another is commune and the thridde is priuee

(base) Thilke penaunce that is solempne is in two maneres as

(base) Another is whan man hath synned
openly of which synne the fame is openly spoken in the contree

(base) Commune penaunce is that preestes enioynen

(base) Pryuee penaunce is thilke that men
doon al day for priuee synnes of whiche we shryue vs pryuely

(base) Now shaltow vnderstande
what bihoueth and is necessarie to verray parfit penitence and
this stant on iij thynges

(base) Contricioun of herte Confessioun of
Mouth and Satisfaccioun

(base) for which seith Seint Iohn Grisostomus
Penitence destreyneth man to accepte benygnely euery peyne that hym

(base) and this is
fruytful penitence agayn iij thynges in whiche we wrathe oure

(base) this is to seyn by delit in thynkynge by recchelesnesse in spekynge by wikked synful wirkynge

(base) and agayns
thise wikkede giltes is penitence that may be likned vn to a tree

(base) And therfore oure Lord Ihesu crist
seith thus by the fruyt of hem shul ye kNowe hem

wol

remembre me alle the yeris of my lyf in bitternesse of myn

trespased to a lord and comth for to axe mercy and maken his accord and set him
doun anon by the lord men wolde holden hym outrageous and nat worthy
so soone for to haue remissioun ne mercy

(base) The thridde signe is how that
thy shrift sholde be ful of teeris if man may and if man may nat wepe with hise bodily eyen lat hym wepe in herte
(base) swich was the confession of seint Peter for after that he hadde forsake Ihesu crist he wente out and weep ful bitterly

(base) The fourthe signe is that he ne lette nat
for shame to shewen his confessioun

(base) swich was the confessioun of the
Magdalene that ne spared for no shame of hem that weren atte feeste
for to go to oure lord Ihesu crist and biknowe to hym hir synnes

(base) The
fifthe signe is that a man or a wonman be obeisant to receyuen
the penaunce that hym is enioyned for hise synnes for certes Ihesu crist
for the giltes of a man was obedient to the deeth

(base) The seconde
condicioun of verray confession is that it be hastily doon for certes if a man
hadde a deedly wounde euere the lenger that he taried to warisshe
hym self the moore wolde it corrupte and haste hym to his deeth
and eek the wounde wolde be the wors for to heele

(base) And right
so fareth synne that longe tyme is in a man vnshewed

(base) Certes a
man oghte hastily shewen hise synnes for manye causes as for
drede of deeth that cometh ofte sodeynly and no certeyn what tyme it
shal be ne in

(base) and eek the lenger that he tarieth the ferther he is fro crist
And if he abide to his laste day scarsly may he shryuen hym or remembre
hym of hise synnes or repenten hym for the greuous maladie of his deeth

(base) and for as muche as he ne hath nat in his lyf herkned Ihesu crist whanne he
hath spoken he shal crie to Ihesu crist at his laste day and scarsly wol he herkne hym

(base) And vnderstond that this condicioun moste han foure thynges Thi
shrift moste be prueyed bifore and auysed for wikked haste dooth no profit

and so forth of the speces and circunstances

(base) and that he haue conperhended in hys
mynde the nombre and the greetnesse of hise synnes and how longe that he
hath leyn in synne

(base) and eek that he be contrit of hise synnes and in stidefast
prpos by the grace of god neuere eft to falle in synne and eek that he drede and
countrewaite hym self that he fle the occasiouns of synne to whiche he
is enclyned

(base) Also thou shalt shryue thee of alle thy synnes to o man
and nat a percel to o man and a percel to another that is to vnderstonde in
entente to deperte thy confessioun as for shame or drede for it nys but stranglynge of thy soule

(base) For certes Ihesu crist is entierly al good in hym nys noon
inperfeccioun and therfore outher he foryeueth al perfitly or neuer a deel

(base) I
seye nat that if thow be assigned to the Penitauncer for certein synne that
thow art bounde to shewen hym al the remenaunt of thy synnes of
whiche thow hast be shryuen to thy curaat but if it like to thee of
thyn humylitee this is no departynge of shrifte

(base) ne I seye nat

of alle thy synnes

(base) but lat no blotte be bihynde lat no synne been
vntoold as fer as thow hast remembraunce

div.l: I preche no thyng / but of couetise
Therfore my teme / is and euere was
Radix omnium malorum / est cupiditas
Thus can I preche / ageyn the same vice
Whiche that I vse / and that is auarice
But though my self / be gilty in that synne
Yit can I make / other folke to wynne
Fro auarice / and sore hem repente
But that is noullȝt / my principal entente
I preche not / but for couetise
Of this matere / it ought ynow suffise
Than telle I hem / ensamples manyoon
Of olde stories / long tyme a goon
For lewed peple / louen tales olde
Suche thinges con they / reporte and holde
What trowe ye / whiles that I may preche
And wynne golde / and syluer for to teche
That I wol lyue in pouert wilfully
Nay nay I thought it neuere trewely
For I wol preche / and begge in sundry londes
I wol do noo labour / with my hondes
Ne maken baskettes / and lyue therby
By cause I wol noullȝt / lyuen ydelly
I wol noon of the Appostelles countrefete
I wol have moneye / chese or whete
Al were it yeven / of the pouerest page
Or of the pouerest widewe / in a village
Al shulde hir childerne sterue / or famyne
And I wol drenken / the licour of the wyne
And have a ioly wenche / in euery toun
But herkeneth lordes / in conclusioun
Youre lykyng is / that I shal telle a tale
Now I have dronken / a draughte of corny ale
By god I hope / I shal telle you a thyng
That by reson / shal be to youre lykyng
For thogh my self / be a vicious man
A moral tale / llȝit I you telle can
Whiche Iames wente to preche / forto wynne
